contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the rule of Zedekiah. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “of the reign of Zedekiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: of Zedekiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they should have said what follows. Alternate translation: “They should have said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They did not say

contextId.occurrenceNote: “There is no hope for us to restrain ourselves.” This implies that they cannot stop themselves from running after other gods. Alternate translation: “We cannot stop ourselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: It is hopeless

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be made clear that they say this to Yahweh. “Yahweh, come and save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise and save us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood on their clothes was evidence that they had killed people. Alternate translation: “The blood of innocent, poor people on your clothes shows that you are guilty of killing them” or “You are guilty of killing poor and innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The blood that was the life of innocent, poor people has been found on your clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will be sad because the army of Egypt will not be able protect them. Alternate translation: “You will be disappointed when Egypt does not protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You will also be disappointed by Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: People made a lot of noise on the hills and mountains when they worshiped false gods. Alternate translation: “We made a confusing noise on the mountains while we worshiped them, but they did not help us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a confusing noise from the mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that Yahweh says this. This is probably his reply to Jeremiah, telling why the battle is still happening. Alternate translation: “Yahweh replied, ‘It is because of the foolishness of my people … do not know to do good.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For the foolishness of my people & do not know to do good.

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the people of Judah as if they were a prostitute making herself look beautiful in order to attract men to her. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Like a prostitute you dress in scarlet … good jewelry … eyes … with paint” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you dress in scarlet & gold jewelry & eyes & with paint

contextId.occurrenceNote: In verses 10-13 Yahweh speaks to Israel’s enemies. This can be made clear in the quotation. Alternate translation: “You enemies of Israel, go up onto her vineyards’ terraces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up onto her vineyards’ terraces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the word” refers to God’s message. Alternate translation: “God’s message is not in them” or “the messages that they speak are not from God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the word is not in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly what kinds of things the prophets were talking about. Alternate translation: “so let the harm that the prophets talk about come to them” or “since the prophets say that bad things will happen to us, let those bad things happen to the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: so let what they say be done to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “these things” refers to sending armies to attack them. Alternate translation: “done all these things to harm us” or “sent foreign armies to attack us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: done all these things to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The trembling would be because of fear, and being “before my face” represents being aware of who God is. Alternate translation: “or shake with fear because of me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: or tremble before my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “keeping the fixed weeks of the harvest” represents making sure that those weeks happen at the right time. Alternate translation: “making sure for us that the weeks of harvest happen when they are supposed to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: keeping the fixed weeks of the harvest for us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated more actively. Alternate translation: “People do terrible and horrible things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Atrocities and horrors have occurred

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the land” refers to the land of Israel.’ Alternate translation: “in the land of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the priests do not submit to God’s authority. Alternate translation: “the priests rule by their own authority” or (2) the priests rule according to the directions of the prophets (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the priests rule with their own power

contextId.occurrenceNote: A trumpet is used as a warning that people will be attacked. Alternate translation: “Blow a trumpet in Tekoa to warn the people that they will be attacked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Blow a trumpet in Tekoa

contextId.occurrenceNote: How the crushing will come can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Enemies will come and crush you” or “Enemies will come and destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a great crushing is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “against her” means “in order to attack Zion.” Alternate translation: “they will set up tents all around Zion in order to attack it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they will set up tents against her all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that the kings say this. Alternate translation: “The kings say to their armies, ‘Dedicate yourselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedicate yourselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The attacking army tries to ensure that their gods will help them during the war by performing ceremonies and making sacrifices to them. Alternate translation: “Prepare for war by purifying yourselves and sacrificing to the gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedicate yourselves to the gods for the battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often spoke of cities as if they were women. Her the word “her” refers to Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the strong buildings of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: her fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly who Yahweh says this to. Alternate translation: “Yahweh says this to the people of Israel” or “Yahweh says this to his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “paid no attention to my word” refers to not listening to what God said, and “rejected it” refers to refusing to obey God’s law. Alternate translation: “They did not listen to what I said. Instead they disobeyed my law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They paid no attention to my word or law, but they instead rejected it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their purpose can be made clear. Alternate translation: “a people is coming to attack you” or “an army is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a people is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “set out in order” means that they have organized themselves and are riding in rows. The phrase “as men for battle” indicates that they are ready to fight. Alternate translation: “they are riding on horses in their assigned rows, and they are ready to fight against you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they are riding on horses, set out in order as men for battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of punishing his people as if they were silver and he was boiling the silver in a very hot fire. These phrases emphasize that the one boiling the metal was working very hard. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The bellows are scorched by the fire that is burning them; the lead is consumed in the flames

contextId.occurrenceNote: The silver has so many impurities in it that the lead is used up before it can remove them all. This represents the people of Israel being so full of sin, that they continue to sin even after God punishes them. Alternate translation: “the silver is so full of impurities, that the lead that is used to remove them is used up” or “they are like silver that is so full of impurities that the lead cannot remove them all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the lead is consumed in the flames

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that, since the temple belongs to Yahweh and represents his presence, he will protect it and the people of Judah will be safe. Possible meanings for why **Temple of Yahweh** is repeated three times are (1) it was repeated for emphasis or (2) it was repeated as part of a temple liturgy. Alternate translation: “This is the temple of Yahweh so it is absolutely certain that no one will destroy it and we are safe.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Temple of Yahweh! Temple of Yahweh! Temple of Yahweh!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was the name of a false god. Alternate translation: “the false god known as ‘the queen of the heavens’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the queen of the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that this is a question that the people of Judah should have been asking. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I have done a terrible thing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What have I done?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that these types of birds know the right times to migrate, which means to fly from one place to another at different times of the year for feeding or breeding. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Even the stork in heaven knows the right times; and the doves, swifts, and cranes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the people should have naturally known Yahweh’s decrees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They go on their migrations at the right time, but my people do not know Yahweh’s decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the people crying a lot. Alternate translation: “so we will cry very hard with tears flowing from our eyes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: so our eyes may run with tears and our eyelids flow with water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people knowing Yahweh and his ways. Alternate translation: “Because people should understand that I am Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he causes the mists to evaporate and form clouds. The phrase “the ends of the earth” refers to all of the earth. Alternate translation: “he causes clouds to form over every part of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he brings up the mists from the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of his people as his “prized possession.” Alternate translation: “Have not my people, who are my prized possession” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Has not my prized possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the cities will be surrounded by their enemies, who will not allow anyone to go in or come out of the cities. Alternate translation: “The cities in the Negev will be shut up, and no one will be able to go into them or come out of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The cities in the Negev will be shut up, with no one to open them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers an enemy army that will come from the north. Alternate translation: “the enemy army coming from the north” or “the enemy army marching from the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the ones coming from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that there is no grass for the deer to eat. Alternate translation: “for there is no grass for them to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for there is no grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for Yahweh. Alternate translation: “You are the hope of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Hope of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Yahweh did not send them out with messages to give to the people. Alternate translation: “I did not send them to prophesy to other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I did not send them out

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to state what they do not know. Alternate translation: “they do not know what they are doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they do not know

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that they are pleading for Yahweh to spare the people. Alternate translation: “were standing in front of me pleading for these people, I would still not be in favor of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: were standing in front of me, I would still not be in favor of this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh was a very wicked king who did many evil things in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “because of the wicked things that Manasseh … did in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: because of what Manasseh & did in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Yahweh will send an enemy army to kill young men, which will cause their mothers great sorrow. Alternate translation: “At noonday I will send an enemy army to destroy young men and cause their mothers to weep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Against the mothers of young men I will send the destroyer at noonday

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to lending money to people. Often lending money causes people to fight with one another. Alternate translation: “I have not lent money to anyone, nor has anyone lent money to me” or “I have not made anyone angry by lending or borrow money and then quarreling about it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I have not lent, nor has anyone lent to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is asking Yahweh not to be patient with the sins of his enemies. The phrase “take me away” refers to him being killed. Alternate translation: “Please do not continue to be patient with them and allow them to kill me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: You are patient, but do not allow them to take me away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “words” represents messages that the prophets speak from Yahweh. Alternate translation: “words of Yahweh from the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: words from the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: These gates are the gates of the king’s palace. Alternate translation: “your people who come to visit the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: your people who come through these gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoiachin has several sons. This phrase, then, means it is as if he was childless. His children will not succeed him as king. Alternate translation: “It will be as if he did not have any children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He will be childless

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Israel, from where they were scattered. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “Then they will live in their own land again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then they will live in their own land

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that they are prophesying falsely. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “they have prophesied falsely anyway” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they have still prophesied

contextId.occurrenceNote: They meant that this dream was from God. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “I had a dream from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I had a dream!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” refers to Yahweh. Here, the phrase **the work of your hands** could mean: (1) it is a reference to the idols that the people have made with their hands. Alternate translation: “do not provoke Yahweh with the idols that you have made” or (2) It is an idiom that refers to the actions of a person, with the word “hands” being a synecdoche that represents the person who does those actions. Alternate translation: “do not provoke Yahweh by the things that you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: do not provoke him with the work of your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly who Yahweh gave this message to. Alternate translation: “this word came to Jeremiah from Yahweh, saying” or “Yahweh spoke this message to Jeremiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: this word came from Yahweh, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit the nature of the time. Alternate translation: “the time for me to destroy his land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the time for his land comes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is telling them they will be there for a long time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Build houses and live in them & lant gardens and eat their fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that Yahweh will give them what they want. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will listen to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit what it was that Jeremiah sent. Alternate translation: “he has sent a message to us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he has sent to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this refers to the people of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time before the exile to Babylon. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “to what they were before I sent the Israelites into exile in Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to what they were before

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the practice of a shepherd counting and inspecting his sheep as the sheep walked under his hand. Alternate translation: “shepherds will again count their sheep as the sheep walk by” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the flocks will again pass under the hands of the ones counting them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah think that they will be safe because the Chaldeans had left. Alternate translation: “Surely we are safe because the Chaldeans are leaving us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Surely the Chaldeans are leaving us

contextId.occurrenceNote: They sent them out to get Jeremiah. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “sent men out to get Jeremiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: sent men out

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit which people the speaker is speaking of. Alternate translation: “among the people who remained in Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: among the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they would give their provisions to Ishmael and his men. Alternate translation: “for we will give you our provisions that we have hidden in a field” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for there are provisions of ours in a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they were afraid that the Chaldeans would attack them. Alternate translation: “because they thought the Chaldeans may attack them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: They desired to live in Egypt. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “in Egypt, where you thought you would be safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the place where you desired to go to live

contextId.occurrenceNote: This a title of a false goddess that the people of Judah worshiped. This goddess is also called “Asherah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: queen of heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah thought they would prosper because the queen of heaven would bless them if they worshiped her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then we will be filled with food and will prosper, without experiencing any disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: Why people burn incense can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “burned incense to false gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: burned incense

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the fourth year of Jehoiakim’s reign. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “in the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fourth year of Jehoiakim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This command can be addressed directly to the soldiers. What they were to go out for can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “You soldiers from Cush and Put, who are skillful with your shields, go out to battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Let the soldiers go out, Cush and Put, men skillful with a shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the destroyer” represents the enemy army. Alternate translation: “For the enemy army will come to every city and destroy it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For the destroyer will come to every city

contextId.occurrenceNote: For wine to taste good, it has to be left undisturbed for a long time and not poured from one pot to another. Yahweh compares the people of Moab, who are prosperous because no one has ever conquered them and taken them as captives, to wine that is undisturbed and has a good flavor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He is like his wine that has never been poured from pot to pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wine makers would stomp on the grapes to squeeze out the juice. Alternate translation: “The wine makers will not stomp the grapes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They will not tread

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemy army has destroyed the people who worship Chemosh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Chemosh’s people are destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “small” represents having the least political importance. Alternate translation: “made you least important” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: made you small

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the people made homes in high places to remain safe from enemies. Alternate translation: “live in safety like an eagle in the heights of the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: so that you may make your nest high like an eagle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the enemies of Babylon. Alternate translation: “You enemies of Babylon arrange yourselves against her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Arrange yourselves against Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: They will escape the destruction of Babylon. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “that I allow to escape the destruction of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: that I spare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the enemies of Babylon. Alternate translation: “You enemies of Babylon, arise against the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise against the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks this to the enemies of Babylon. This can be made clear. Alternate translation: “You enemies of Babylon, kill all her bulls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Kill all her bulls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks this to the people of Babylon. This can be made clear. Alternate translation: “See, I am against you, people of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: See, I am against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the people of Babylon. This can be made clear. Alternate translation: “See, people of Babylon, a people is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: See, a people is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit was about 46 centimeters long. Alternate translation: “18 cubits … 12 cubits” or “about 8.3 meters … about 5.5 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: eighteen cubits & twelve cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit was about 46 centimeters long. Alternate translation: “5 cubits” or “about 2.3 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: five cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shekel is 11 grams. Alternate translation: “17 shekels” or “187 grams” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bmoney]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: seventeen shekels

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of July and the first part of August on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the fifth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the dry season. It is during the last part of July and the first part of August on Western calendars. This was after Zedekiah had been king for three years. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fourth year and the fifth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of September and the first part of October on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the seventh month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the ninth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of November and the first part of December on Western calendars. “after Jehoiakim … had been king of Judah for more than four years, during the ninth month” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fifth year and ninth month of Jehoiakim & king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the ninth month of the Hebrew calendar. This is at the end of the sowing season and the beginning of the cold season. It is during the last part November and the first part of December on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ninth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is after Zedekiah had been king of Judah for eight years, in the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of December and the first part of January on Western calendars. Alternate translation: “In the tenth month of the ninth year that Zedekiah was king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: In the ninth year and tenth month of Zedekiah king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is after Zedekiah had been king of Judah for more than ten years, in the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar. The eleventh day is near the beginning of July on Western calendars. Alternate translation: “On the ninth day of the fourth month of the eleventh year that Zedekiah was king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: In the eleventh year and fourth month of Zedekiah, on the ninth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of September and the first part of October on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the seventh month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. The tenth day is near the beginning of January on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the tenth month, and on the tenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the dry season. The ninth day is near the beginning of July on Western calendars. Zedekiah had been king for ten years, three months, and eight days. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: By the ninth day of the fourth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar had been king for eighteen years, four months, and nine days. This is the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the dry season. The tenth day is near the beginning of August on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month, which was the nineteenth year of the reign of King Nebuchadnezzar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the twelfth and last month of the Hebrew calendar. The twenty-fifth day is near the middle of March on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hilkiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Anathoth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Amon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Kittim was an island west of Israel. Today it is called Cyprus. It represented all the lands far to the west of Israel. Alternate translation: “go west across the ocean to Kittim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: cross over to the coasts of Kittim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Kedar is the name of a land far to the east of Israel. Alternate translation: “Send messengers far east to the land of Kedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Send messengers out to Kedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of two cities in Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Memphis and Tahpanhes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a stream associated with Egypt. It may have been a branch of the Nile River. Some versions call it the Nile. Alternate translation: “the Shihor Stream” or “the Shihor River” or “the Nile River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Shihor

contextId.occurrenceNote: An Arab is a person from Arabia. Some Arabs lived as nomads in the desert and would rob others who came near them. Alternate translation: “a nomad in the wilderness” or “a robber in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: an Arab in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town about 18 kilometers south of Jerusalem. The name means “a horn for blowing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Tekoa

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place where the people of Israel sacrificed their children to a false god by burning them with fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the high place of Topheth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a valley south of the city of Jerusalem, where people sacrificed to false gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Valley of Ben Hinnom

contextId.occurrenceNote: places where silver and gold are mined (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Tarshish & Uphaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a special city where priests live. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Anathoth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Pashhur & Immer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name means “terror on every side” or “surrounded by terror.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: you are Magor Missabib

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Pashhur & Malkijah & Maaseiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name in Hebrew is “Shallum,” but he is better known as Jehoahaz. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jehoahaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: a mountain range that was southeast of Jerusalem (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Abarim mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Amon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Uz

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedan, Tema, and Buz

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Zimri

contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

contextId.quoteString: Ishmael & Nethaniah & Johanan & Jonathan & Kareah & Seraiah & Tanhumeth & Ephai & Jaazaniah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Baalis

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Elishama

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Geruth Kimham

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jezaniah & Hoshaiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. The name means “city of the sun.” In this city was a temple where they worshiped a sun god. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Heliopolis

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Migdol

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hophra

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Necho

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city on the west bank of the Euphrates. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are biblical names for the countries of Ethiopia and Libya. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Cush & Put

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of the people group from the nation of Lud. Lud is the biblical name for Lydia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ludim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a mountain in the northern part of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Mount Tabor

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Amon” is the king of the Egyptian gods. “Thebes” is the capital of the northern part of Egypt, and here it represents the people of Thebes. Alternate translation: “Amon, god of Thebes” or “Amon, god of the people of Thebes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Amon of Thebes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of an island of the northern region of the Philistines. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Caphtor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city near Mount Nebo in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebo

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kiriathaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Heshbon

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Madmen” here is a town in Moab. The name of the city has nothing to do with the English word “madmen.” Alternate translation: “Their enemies will destroy the city of Madmen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Madmen will also perish

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town in the south of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Horonaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Luhith

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Chemosh” is the chief god of the Moabites. This means the enemy army will take the idol of Chemosh that the people made to worship. Alternate translation: “The enemy army will take your god Chemosh as a captive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then Chemosh will go away into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dibon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Aroer

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are cities in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Holon, Jahzah, and Mephaath

contextId.occurrenceNote: a city in Moab (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of the old capital city of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir Hareseth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of two towns in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jazer & Sibmah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of other cities in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Elealeh & Jahaz & Zoar & Horonaim & Eglath Shelishiyah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a stream or river near the Dead Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nimrim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of an Amorite king who once ruled over Heshbon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sihon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a district in Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Teman

contextId.occurrenceNote: The is the name of a city in Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city in Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are cities in Syria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamath and Arpad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This the name or title of the king of Damascus. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ben Hadad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of kingdom or district far to the east of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hazor

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are two names for the chief god of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bel & Marduk

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for Babylon. This is a name that means “double rebellion.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Merathaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for the Chaldeans. This is a name that means “visitation.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Pekod

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is code name for Chaldea, a region of Babylonia. It is not clear why Jeremiah uses this name here, so you may want to translate as “Chaldea” or “Babylonia.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Leb Kamai

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of nations or people groups. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ararat & Minni & Ashkenaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Seraiah & Neriah & Mahseiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamutal

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Libnah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to another man named Jeremiah, not the prophet Jeremiah who wrote this book. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Riblah was a town in the territory of Hamath. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: at Riblah in the land of Hamath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuzaradan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuzaradan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Riblah

contextId.occurrenceNote: He became the king of Babylon after Nebuchadnezzar. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Awel-Marduk

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbol of shame. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: with your hands on your head

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would wear sackcloth to show that they were very sad. In this context it would be to show that they were very sorry for the bad things they had done. Alternate translation: “put on the clothes that show you are mourning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: wrap yourself in sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: People do these things to show that they are extremely sad. Alternate translation: “Show how sad you are by wearing sackcloth and rolling in ashes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: put on sackcloth and roll in ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This would be done as a sign of mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Cut off your hair and shave yourself, and throw away your hair

contextId.occurrenceNote: A king and queen mother wear crowns to represent their royal positions as the king and queen mother. Also, this event has not happened yet, but it is written here as if it already has. This can be written in future tense. Alternate translation: “for you will no longer be the king and queen mother, for your crowns, your pride and glory, will fall off” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: for your splendid crowns have fallen from your heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: In biblical times, people would wear a headcovering to show that they were ashamed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they cover their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: In biblical times, people would wear a headcovering to show that they were ashamed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: The plowmen are ashamed and cover their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Cutting oneself and shaving one’s head were symbolic actions that expressed strong grief, especially when a loved one died. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: no one will & cut themselves or shave their heads for them

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will turn my back toward them, and not my face.” Turning one’s back towards someone is a symbolic action that represents rejection and turning one’s face towards someone is a symbolic action that represents favor. Alternate translation: “I will reject them and not act favorably towards them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I will show them my back, and not my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This symbolic act represents surrender. Alternate translation: “surrendering to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: falling on his knees before

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a sign of sorrow, mourning or distress. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Roll about in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: One turns one’s face to someone to show that one is listening, and one’s back to show that one refuses to listen. Alternate translation: “Instead of listening carefully to me, they refused to listen at all” or “They refused to listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: They turned their backs to me instead of their faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: People tore their cloths when they were extremely sad. Alternate translation: “nor did they mourn by tearing their clothes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: nor did they tear their clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The shaving of the entire head or portions of the head is a sign of great sorrow practiced by idol worshipers in nations such as Philistia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Baldness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The cutting of one’s skin was another practice done by the idol worshipers when they mourn the dead. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: cut yourself in mourning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbolic action that shows feeling of scorn or disgust towards someone. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: shook your head at him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all things that the people of Moab did when they were mourning or expressing deep sorrow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: For every head is bald and every beard shaved & ncisions are on every hand, and sackcloth is around their waists

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hiss” refers to a sound that shows horror or awe. Alternate translation: “shake from fear and gasp” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: tremble and hiss

contextId.occurrenceNote: An almond tree is a kind of nut tree. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: an almond branch

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bellows are a tool used to blow large amounts of air into a burning fire to make the fire hotter. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: The bellows are scorched

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these are different types of birds that migrate. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: stork & doves, swifts, and cranes

contextId.occurrenceNote: musical instruments with heads like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around their sides that sound when the instruments are shaken (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: tambourines

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exclamation that expresses God’s desire. Alternate translation: “I want so much to treat you as my son … nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: How I want to treat you as my son & nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “How” begins exclamations. The phrase “has been shattered” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I have completely shattered them! They shout loudly and weep!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: How it has been shattered! How they howl in their lamenting!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking. The command “Make him drunk” indicates what Yahweh will cause to happen. Here “him” and “he” refers to Moab which represents the people of Moab. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, will cause the people of Moab to be drunk, for they acted proudly against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-imperative]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Make him drunk, because he acted proudly against Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh speaks of what will happen as if it had already happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The long quotation that begins with the words “The word of Yahweh” in verse 6 ends here. You may translate this as indirect speech. Alternate translation: “Jeremiah said that the word of Yahweh had come to him and told him that Hanamel son of Shallum his uncle was coming to him and would tell him to buy his uncle’s field that was in Anathoth for himself, for the right to buy it belonged to Jeremiah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: ‘Look, Hanamel son of Shallum your uncle is coming to you and will say, “Buy my field that is in Anathoth for yourself, for the right to buy it belongs to you & ”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This part of the story is used to provide historical information to show when the events of the happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: This vision happened & them to Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “woe” here indicates that in this prayer Jeremiah is sad, complaining or lamenting. The word “look” here indicates that the next words are an introduction or background for the most important part of the prayer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe, Lord Yahweh! Look!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words begin to provide background information to events that will be described later. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: after King Zedekiah had made a covenant & freedom to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The background information that begins with the words “after King Zedekiah had made a covenant” in verse 8 ends here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: that each man & his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words begin to describe how the people established the covenant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: when they cut a bull & walked between its parts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The description of how the people established the covenant that began with the words “when they cut” in verse 18 ends here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: and then the leaders & walked between the parts of the bull

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word is used here to mark a break in the main story line. The narrator tells background information about what Jeremiah had been doing before Zedekiah sent the message. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Now

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “now” marks a break in the main story line where the narrator tells background information about what the king was doing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Now the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information about the cistern that Ishmael used. King Asa had his men dig the cistern so his people would have a water supply when King Baasha attacked them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: The cistern where Ishmael & against King Baasha of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author stops the story to refer to a previous event so that the order of events are understood. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: This was after Ishmael had killed Gedaliah son of Ahikam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “now” introduces background information about Nebuchadnezzar. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: now Nebuchadnezzar

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]]
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]]
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]]
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

God gives Jeremiah a message about Babylon. See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]]
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are a proverb that Jeremiah heard people say when they were complaining that Yahweh was punishing children for the sins of their fathers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-proverbs]])
contextId.quoteString: Fathers have eaten sour grapes, but the children’s teeth are dulled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah restates the proverb so that it now means people will suffer as a consequence of their own behaviors. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-proverbs]])
contextId.quoteString: everyone who eats sour grapes, his teeth will be dulled

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is speaking to the people of nations far away from him as if they could hear him. He is speaking as if to the earth itself. Alternate translation: “Listen, everyone who lives on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Hear, earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks here in the form of a command to strengthen what he says. This command is not directed to a specific person and may be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “Let all the wild beasts in the fields come and eat her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Go and gather all the wild beasts and bring them to devour her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah pretends to speak to his mother as a way to emphasize how sad he is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to me, my mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks his message to all the people of the land by calling out to the land where they live. The title is repeated to call attention to the message. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Land, Land, Land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking in an apostrophe to all people of the world, so these verbs are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Shout & Shout & Let praise be heard & Say

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is on the top of a hill, and the temple was built at the highest point in Jerusalem. AT; “May Yahweh bless those who live in Jerusalem with Yahweh, where his temple is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: May Yahweh bless you, you righteous place where he lives, you holy mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is speaking to Nebuchadnezzar as if he was there listening to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise! Attack & themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is still speaking to Nebuchadnezzar as if he were there listening to him. This can be stated in second person. Alternate translation: “For your soldiers will take their camels and all of their property” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: For their camels will become plunder, and the abundance of their property will become war plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah is speaking to the people of Jerusalem as if he were speaking to the people of Babylon and their enemies, who cannot hear him, telling them that Yahweh will destroy Babylon before the Babylonians can prepare to defend themselves. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh speaks to the people of Jerusalem, who could hear him, as if he were speaking to the people of Babylon, who could not hear him. He speaks to the city of Babylon as if he were speaking to the people of Babylon itself. He speaks of the city as if it were a mountain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “will certainly punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: will certainly not leave you unpunished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “will certainly punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: will certainly not leave you unpunished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “I will scatter the people of Elam to every nation on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: There is no nation to which those scattered from Elam will not go

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah uses these words, which mean almost the same thing, to show that this will certainly happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to destroy and overthrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing. The phrase “a great collapse” defines what the “disaster” will be. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: disaster & a great collapse

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “winnow” and “cleanse” refer to blowing away the useless skins from grain. Only a light wind was needed for that. Alternate translation: “It will not be a light wind for blowing the chaff away from the grain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It will not winnow or cleanse them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how long the nation has existed. This refers to the nation from far away that Yahweh will bring against Israel. Alternate translation: “it is a very old and enduring nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: it is a lasting nation, an ancient nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of Yahweh’s anger. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: anger and wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: they did not listen or pay attention

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words have similar meanings and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: rejected and abandoned

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean almost the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. The abstract nouns “joy” and “gladness” can be translated using the verb “rejoicing” and the adjective “glad.” Alternate translation: “the sounds of people rejoicing and being glad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the sound of joy and the sound of gladness

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two things mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: paid attention and listened

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “brutish” and “stupid” mean basically the same thing and emphasize how foolish the people are for worshiping idols. Alternate translation: “They are all very stupid, they are disciples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: They are all the same, they are brutish and stupid, disciples

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these words have similar meaning and together emphasize that the servants were ashamed that they were unable to get water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: ashamed and dishonored

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ashamed” and “embarrassed” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of shame. Alternate translation: “She will be completely ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: She will be ashamed and embarrassed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “controversy” and “argument” mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize how much Jeremiah is arguing. Alternate translation: “a man with whom everyone argues all the time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: a man of controversy and argument

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “calamity” and “distress” mean basically the same thing. They emphasize the amount or intensity of the calamity. Alternate translation: “in the time of great calamity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: in the time of calamity and distress

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wealth” and “treasures” mean the same thing and refer to anything that people consider to be valuable. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: wealth and treasures

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “save” and “rescue” mean the same thing and emphasize the safety that God promises. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: save and rescue

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wealth” and “treasures” mean the same thing and refer to anything that they consider valuable. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: your wealth and all your treasures

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “barren land without inhabitants” describes and means basically the same thing as “wilderness.” Alternate translation: “the barren wilderness where no person lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the wilderness, barren land without inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people refused to listen. Alternate translation: “They refused to listen” or “They refused to obey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: They did not listen or pay attention

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two expressions basically mean the same thing. In the first expression, Yahweh speaks of destroying a kingdom as if the kingdom were a plant or a building that he tears down. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: tear it down, or destroy it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Yahweh speaks of strengthening kingdoms as if they were buildings that he would build, and as if they were plants that he would plant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: build it up or plant it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ways” and “practices” both refer to a person’s actions and general lifestyle. Alternate translation: “so your actions will result in good happening to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: so your ways and your practices will bring good to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he proclaimed Yahweh’s message boldly. Alternate translation: “openly proclaimed” or “proclaimed loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: called out and proclaimed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “reproach” and “mocking” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that people have ridiculed Jeremiah for proclaiming Yahweh’s message. Alternate translation: “a reason for people to ridicule me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: for me reproach and mocking

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “troubles” and “agony” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the amount and severity of suffering. Alternate translation: “to experience so much suffering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to see troubles and agony

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words all mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the great intensity of his anger. Alternate translation: “with extremely great anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with wrath, fury, and great anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases have the same meaning and emphasize that Nebuchadnezzar will deal severely with them. Alternate translation: “He will not show them any mercy or compassion at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: He will not pity them, spare them, or have compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. The phrase “bowed down” describes the posture that people used in worship. Alternate translation: “they worshiped other gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: bowed down to other gods and worshiped them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “unrighteousness” and “injustice” have similar meanings, are repeated for emphasis, and can be stated as actions. Alternate translation: “unjustly forced men to build his house and his upper rooms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: builds his house by unrighteousness, his upper rooms by injustice

contextId.occurrenceNote: These abstract nouns have similar meanings, are repeated for emphasis and can be stated as actions. Alternate translation: “act justly and fairly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: do justice and righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: You have scattered my flock and have driven them away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “increase” explains how they will be “fruitful.” Alternate translation: “they will increase greatly in number” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be fruitful and increase

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “be shattered” mean that someone has caused them to be afraid and mean basically the same thing as “fear.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will make them afraid anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will no longer fear or be shattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: “who brought back” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: who brought up and who led back

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the false prophets made up their prophesies. Alternate translation: “prophesy things that come only from their own minds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: prophesy lies from their minds & prophesy from the deceit in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how thoroughly Yahweh will judge the people of Jerusalem. They will become something that will frighten other people when they see it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn them into a frightening thing, a disaster & a disgrace and a subject for proverbs, taunts, and curses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The terms “wicked way” and “corruption of his practices” mean the same thing and refer to every sinful thing that they do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: his wicked way and the corruption of his practices

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The idiom “the works of their hands” refers to the actions of a person, with the word “hands” being a synecdoche that represents the person who does those actions. Alternate translation: “everything that they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: their deeds and the works of their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean almost the same thing. Alternate translation: “the things you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: your ways & your practices

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “good” and “right” mean the same thing. The eye is a metonym for the person’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “Do to me whatever you think is the right thing to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Do to me what is good and right in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are two ways of speaking of the same people, perhaps first as a group and then as individuals. The city is a metonym for the people in the city. Alternate translation: “all the people in the city and every one of the people who live here” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: this city and its inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ashamed” and “humiliated” mean basically the same thing and intensify the idea of shame. Alternate translation: “I was completely ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I was ashamed and humiliated

contextId.occurrenceNote: All three words mean the same thing and emphasize how very angry he is. Alternate translation: “extreme anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: wrath, fury, and great anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Together, these two phrases form an idiomatic expression that refers to a person’s entire being. Alternate translation: “with all that I am” or “wholeheartedly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: with all my heart and all my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wrath” and “fury” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his wrath. Alternate translation: “in my extreme wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: in my wrath and fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in that time” means the same thing as, and intensifies the phrase “In those days.” Alternate translation: “In those very days” or “At that very time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: In those days and in that time

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here these words share similar meanings. They describe Yahweh as a witness whom no one will be able to contradict. Alternate translation: “trustworthy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: true and faithful

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “save” and “rescue” mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will, indeed, save. Alternate translation: “to save you completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to save you and rescue you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wrath” and “fury” mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the intensity of his wrath. Alternate translation: “my terrible wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my wrath and my fury
