contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “fury” and “wrath” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his wrath. Alternate translation: “my terrible wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my fury and my wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ruins” and “devastations” mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the complete devastation of Judah and Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “they became completely devastated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: they became ruins and devastations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that no one, not even the strongest and fastest, can escape. The nominal adjective “the swift” can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “even the swiftest soldier cannot escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the swift cannot run away, and the soldiers cannot escape

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase have similar meanings and they are combined to emphasize the loud noise they will make. Alternate translation: “at the very loud sound of the wheels of the chariots” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: at the roar of their chariots and the noise of their wheels

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two terms mean the same thing. Together they emphasize complete destruction. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: ruin and great destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These terms mean the same thing and are used to emphasize how happy they were to conquer Israel. Alternate translation: “You people of Babylon rejoice, celebrate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You rejoice, you celebrate

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of her embarrassment. The words “mother” and “the one who bore you” refer either to Babylonia or to the city of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So your mother will be greatly ashamed; the one who bore you will be embarrassed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words have basically the same meaning and emphasize the complete barrenness of the land. This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor for an uninhabited place or (2) this refers to Babylon literally becoming a barren wilderness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a wilderness, a dry land, and a desert

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they strengthen the command for foreigners to flee from Babylon back to their own countries. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Let each person turn back to his own people & let them flee to their own land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “their day” and “the time” mean the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: “the time for their punishment has come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: their day has come—the time for their punishment

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to the same people and are repeated for poetic effect. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the archers & those who bend their bows

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. The second phrase defines the “day” that the first phrase mentions. Alternate translation: “for the day when I will punish you has come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: for your day has come & the time when I will punish you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Babylon will be completely uninhabited. Alternate translation: “People will never live there again; it will be uninhabited forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: For all time, she will no longer be inhabited & rom generation to generation, she will not be lived in

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Babylon will be completely uninhabited. They can be combined. Alternate translation: “no one will ever live there again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: no one will live there; no person will stay in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will” and “forget” are understood to be part of the second phrase also. Alternate translation: “Will a virgin forget her jewelry, and will a bride forget her veils” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Will a virgin forget her jewelry, a bride her veils

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “disappointed” is understood from the previous phrase. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “just as you were disappointed by Assyria” or “just as Assyria disappointed you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: just as you were by Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that this is what the people of Israel will say. Alternate translation: “The people will reply, ‘Behold! We will come to you” or “You will say “Behold! We will come to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Behold! We will come to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “are destroyed” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “my curtains are destroyed in a moment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: my curtains in a moment

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will be taken” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “every old person heavy with years will be taken” or “they will take every old person heavy with years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: every old person heavy with years

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “will be turned over to others” is understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “and their fields and their women will also be turned over to others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: both their fields and their wives together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “will stumble” is understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “fathers and sons will both stumble” or “fathers and sons will both be hurt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: fathers and sons together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “that neither they nor their ancestors have known” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: neither they nor their ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “teach each neighbor woman a funeral song” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: each neighbor woman a funeral song

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “or let the warrior take pride in his might” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: or the warrior in his might

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to while the person is running. Alternate translation: “If you fall down while running” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: If you fall down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “I will smash fathers and children together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: fathers and children together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “we hoped for a time of healing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: for a time of healing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “then go and stand in all the other gates of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: then in all the other gates of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will never perish” can be supplied to each of these phrases. This can also be expressed in positive terms. Alternate translation: “the law will never perish from the priests, and advice will never perish from the wise men, and words will never perish from the prophets” or “the priests will always have the law, the wise men will always give advice, and the prophets will always speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the law will never perish from the priests, or advice from the wise men, or words from the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “let people kill their men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their men be killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “let people kill their young men with swords in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their young men killed by the sword in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. The idiom “fall … by the hand of” means to be killed by someone, with the word “hand” representing the whole person. Alternate translation: “I will enable those who want to kill them to kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: by the hand of the ones seeking their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “the houses” may be supplied here. Alternate translation: “the houses of the kings of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: of the kings of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence lists all who will be powerful and wealthy. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “he, his servants, and his people will ride into the palace on chariots and horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: he, his servants, and his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: In verse 18, Yahweh stops speaking directly to Jehoiakim and begins to speak to other people. Here “lament” refers to grieving at Jehoiakim’s death. Alternate translation: “They will not lament for Jehoiakim when he dies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: They will not lament for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make this a complete sentence. Alternate translation: “Jeremiah should hide himself, too” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeremiah, too

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “of the rule” are understood. Alternate translation: “in the fourth year of the rule of Jehoiakim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fourth year of Jehoiakim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ideas of soldiers and going out to battle are understood from earlier in the sentence. They can be repeated. This command can also be addressed directly to the soldiers. Alternate translation: “you soldiers from Lud, who are skillful at bending your bows, go out to battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Ludim, men skillful at bending their bows

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood “Gather together” is the beginning of the messenger’s message. Alternate translation: “to tell the nations, ‘Gather together … for battle.’” or “to the nations, and he will tell them, ‘Gather together … for battle.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: to the nations, ‘Gather together & for battle.’

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the enemy soldiers will rape the Judean women. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the enemy soldiers will lift up the skirts of your women and rape them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that your skirts are raised up and you have been violated

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put an end to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “come to an end” is a mild way to say that they will die. The word “sword” represents an army whose soldiers fight with swords. The phrase represents dying in battle. Alternate translation: “they will die in battle or from famine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will come to an end by sword and famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word usually refers to cooking food over an open fire or in a pan, not to burning completely. This could mean: (1) this is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “burned to death” or (2) the king’s men attached them to poles over the fire close enough that the fire would slowly kill them but far enough away that it would not totally consume their bodies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: roasted

contextId.occurrenceNote: “But I will not completely destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: But I will certainly not put an end to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way to say that they wanted to kill them. Alternate translation: “seeking to kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: seeking their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a metonym for dying in war. Alternate translation: “No one will kill you with their sword” or “You will not die in war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the people will be silent because they are mourning or (2) this is a euphemism that means the enemy soldiers will kill them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: the people & will be made silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “bitter” describes “wicked.” Alternate translation: “it is bitterly wicked” or “it is extremely wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]])
contextId.quoteString: it is wicked and bitter

contextId.occurrenceNote: This hendiadys is also an idiom that means something is done many times. Alternate translation: “repeatedly” or “persistently” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: time and time again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hendiadys “fear and tremble” can be translated by a single verb. Alternate translation: “they will tremble with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]])
contextId.quoteString: they will fear and tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah may have been exaggerating to show his fear of speaking in public. Alternate translation: “I do not know how to speak in public” or “I do not know how to make announcements to people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: I do not know how to speak

contextId.occurrenceNote: This generalization refers to the kings of the northern kingdoms. Alternate translation: “every king” or “all of the northern kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: everyone

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tops of hills and under shade trees were common places for people to worship idols. The word “every” is used as a generalization to show that the people were worshiping idols in many different places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: every high hill and under every leafy tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would worship idols under trees. The word “every” is a generalization used to show that the people of Israel worshiped many gods under many different trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: under every leafy tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization that means over this entire period of time, not every day during this period of time. Alternate translation: “From the time your ancestors went out from the land of Egypt until now” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: Ever since the day when your ancestors went out from the land of Egypt until this day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration that is a metaphor for the people of Judah trembling with fear. Alternate translation: “All the people of the land shake with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The whole earth shakes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are an exaggeration that express the great extent of Jeremiah’s sorrow. Alternate translation: “is very great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: has no end

contextId.occurrenceNote: “than the grains of sand on the seashore.” This comparison is an exaggeration used to emphasize an uncountable number. Alternate translation: “more than you can count” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: more than the sands of the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is spoken of as if it were a container and the adulterers were objects that filled the container completely. That is, everyone in the land is an adulterer, which in turn is an exaggeration for very many people being adulterers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: the land is full of adulterers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “constantly” is an exaggeration to emphasize that this is what they normally say. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: They are constantly saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: The world “never” is a generalization. The Israelites will almost always feel joy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: they will never again feel any more sorrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: They literally “lowered Jeremiah down on ropes,” but the word “threw” is an exaggeration to say that they treated him roughly. Your language may have another way of saying this. Alternate translation: “they … roughly pushed him into the cistern” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: they & threw him into the cistern

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is probably a generalization. Alternate translation: “the people who were still living in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: the rest of the people who were left in the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nothing” is probably an exaggeration. Alternate translation: “who owned nothing of great value” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: who had nothing for themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “all” is a generalization. Alternate translation: “many of the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Most likely not every individual in the town went. The word “all” is a generalization that means very many people went. Alternate translation: “many other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Most likely not every individual in the town went. The word “all” is a generalization that means very many people went. Alternate translation: “to many other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: to all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably did not include every individual there. The word “all” is a generalization that means many people. Alternate translation: “many of the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Every person” is a generalization that means “very many people.” Also, “sword” represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “Nearly every person of Judah in the land of Egypt will die. Enemies will kill many of them and many of them will starve to death until there is very few of them left” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Every person of Judah in the land of Egypt will perish by sword and famine until they are all finished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to announce that God gave messages to him. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave messages to him” or “Yahweh spoke to Jeremiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh came to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “in the days of” is an idiom that refers to the time when a king reigned. Alternate translation: “when Josiah son of Amon was king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the days of Josiah son of Amon, king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “in the days of” is an idiom that refers to the time when a king reigned. Alternate translation: “when Johoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the days of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave me a message. He said” or “Yahweh spoke this message to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh came to me, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an idiom referring to the time when a female donkey wants to mate with male donkeys. Alternate translation: “when she wants to mate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in her heat

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that someone discovers that the person’s actions. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when someone finds him” or “when people know that he has stolen things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: when he is found

contextId.occurrenceNote: “As surely as Yahweh is alive.” The people use this expression to show that what they say next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Alternate translation: “I solemnly swear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: As Yahweh lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to starting to move. Alternate translation: “is starting to march” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: is setting out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “come upon us” means “happen to us.” Alternate translation: “No harm will happen to us” or “no one will harm us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: no harm will come upon us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Find safety” represents doing what they can in order to be safe. Alternate translation: “Be safe … by leaving Jerusalem” or “Leave Jerusalem … so that you can be safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Find safety & by leaving Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These things being “before” God’s face represents him seeing them. Alternate translation: “I constantly see sickness and wounds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: sickness and wounds are continually before my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to announce that God gave messages to them. He did this through his prophets. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has sent messages to them” or “Yahweh has spoken to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh has come to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is speaking. He feels the same anger that Yahweh feels, and he speaks of being extremely angry as if he were filled with anger. Alternate translation: “I am completely angry as Yahweh is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: But I am filled with Yahweh’s fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “heavy with years” is an idiom that means “very old.” It reinforces the phrase “old person.” Alternate translation: “every very old person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: every old person heavy with years

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s temple is spoken of as if it was carrying the name of Yahweh. This has a similar meaning to “this house that is called by my name” in the previous verse. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: this house, which carries my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “where I allowed my name to stay” is an idiom that means this was a place where Yahweh was worshiped. Alternate translation: “the place in Shiloh where I first allowed my people to worship me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: my place that was in Shiloh, where I allowed my name to stay there in the beginning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his anger as if it were something that could be poured out. Alternate translation: “I will punish this place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: my anger and wrath will gush out onto this place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his anger as if it were a fire that could not be put out. Alternate translation: “No one will be able to stop my anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: It will burn and never be extinguished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means they were stubborn. Alternate translation: “they became stubborn” or “they resisted me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they hardened their necks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom for Yahweh’s judgment on his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He will make us drink poison

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “consume” means to eat up. It is an idiom for how the enemies come and destroy the land and its inhabitants. Alternate translation: “they will come and destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they will come and consume

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walking” is an idiom for living. Alternate translation: “every neighbor slanders one another” or “every neighbor is a slanderer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: every neighbor walks in slander

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this word here to draw Jeremiah’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walk” is an idiom for “live.” Alternate translation: “or live the way I tell them to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: or walk by it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this word here to draw the people’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “tell the women to come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: let them come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh tells what the people of Judah will say when the land is destroyed. Alternate translation: “We are very upset” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: How we are devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this word here to draw the people’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen” or “Indeed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this word here to draw the peoples’ attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that do not worship you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: that do not call on your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “obey them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: carry them out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walking” is an idiom for the way a person lives. The word “heart” is a metonym for a person’s desires and emotions. Alternate translation: “Each person has refused to change and has been living by his own wicked desires” or “Each person has refused to change and continues to do the evil things that they want to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Each person has been walking in the stubbornness of his wicked heart.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “cut him off” means to destroy him. Also, “the living” refers to living people. Alternate translation: “Let us kill him so he is no longer in the land of those who are alive” or “Let us destroy him so that he is no longer among the world of living people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Let us cut him off from the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “year” here is a idiom that describes a specific period of time that Yahweh decides. Alternate translation: “in the time of their punishment” or “for the time of their punishment is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: a year of their punishment

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “cares” or “pays any attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: takes it to heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “who are stubborn and only do the things they desire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who walk in the hardness of their heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “look” is an idiom that means to pay attention and be aware of what is happening. Also, “Lift up your eyes” represents looking at something. Alternate translation: “Pay attention and be aware of the ones coming from the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift up your eyes and look at the ones coming from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “going up” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “They are calling out loudly in prayer for Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: their cries for Jerusalem are going up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “remembers” or “recalls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: calls to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “happen to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: fall on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “will grow faint” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will waste away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I did not spend time with” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I did not sit in the circle of

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means during their lifetime. Alternate translation: “during your lifetime” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in your days

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “to fill” means that they have placed many idols in the land. The words “their filling” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “because they have filled my inheritance with their disgusting idols” or “because their disgusting idols are everywhere in my inheritance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: for their filling my inheritance with their disgusting idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means the farthest places on the earth. By referencing both ends, it refers to everywhere in between. Alternate translation: “the farthest places on the earth” or “everywhere on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “days” stands for someone’s entire life. Alternate translation: “when he has lived only half of his life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: when half his days are over

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, this idiom could mean: (1) the people do not care about what Jeremiah will say to them. Alternate translation: “We do not care what you say” or (2) The people do not think that anything good will come of what Jeremiah tells them to do. Alternate translation: “What you are saying will not work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: This is no use

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “give over” means to place a person in the power of another person. Jeremiah speaks of “famine” as if it were a person who could have power over others. Alternate translation: “cause their children to die from famine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: give their children over to famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ears … will tingle” is an idiom that means everyone will be shocked by what they hear. Alternate translation: “it will shock everyone who hears of it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “to fall by the sword” means to die in battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will enable their enemies to kill them with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make them to fall by the sword before their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “fall by the sword” means that they will die in battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “their enemies will kill them with swords” or “their enemies will kill them in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will fall by the sword of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases are idiomatic expressions that refer to great power. Alternate translation: “with very great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with a raised hand and a strong arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he “firmly decided.” Alternate translation: “I have made up my mind to oppose this city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I have set my face against this city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pour out … blood” is associated with murder, and “blood” refers to the murdered people. Alternate translation: “Do not … murder innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not & pour out innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pouring out … blood” is associated with murder, and “blood” refers to the murdered people. Alternate translation: “murdering innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: pouring out innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to shouting. In this case, they are crying out in grief. Alternate translation: “Cry out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift your voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he will appoint a successor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will raise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to deep sadness. Alternate translation: “I am very sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart is broken in me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they lived a life of deceit. Alternate translation: “live in dishonesty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: walk in deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they would stop doing these things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: to turn from

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “look on” is an idiom that means Yahweh will take care of them. Alternate translation: “I will take good care of the exiles of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will look on the exiles of Judah for their benefit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom to “bring … against this land” means that they will attack the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “bring them to attack this land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: bring them against this land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “set … apart for destruction” means to destroy something completely. Alternate translation: “I will destroy them completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set them apart for destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means every person, one after another. Alternate translation: “one after another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: everyone with his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means the farthest places on the earth. By referencing both ends, it refers to everywhere in between. Alternate translation: “to the farthest places on the earth” or “to everywhere on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: to the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “raised arm” refers to great power and intensifies the first phrase. Alternate translation: “by my very great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: by my great strength and my raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “found favor” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “While the people who have survived the sword have been in the wilderness, I have had grace on them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The people who have survived the sword have found favor in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: in grief. If people use a different phrase or action in your language to show that they are very sad, you may want to use it here. Alternate translation: “I rubbed my brow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I slapped my thigh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the people will be so safe that women will not need anyone to protect them or (2) this is an idiom for something no one would ever expect. Alternate translation: “new on earth—something as strange as a woman protecting a man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: new on earth—a woman surrounds a strong man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. “place where you were slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: house of slavery

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “coming and going” is an idiom that means he was free to move about. Alternate translation: “Jeremiah was able to go wherever he wanted with everybody else” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeremiah was coming and going among the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: King Zedekiah was probably hearing and judging legal cases. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: sitting at the Benjamin Gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “keep nothing back from you” is an idiom that means to tell someone everything. This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “I will tell you everything the Lord tells me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I will keep nothing back from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “been a witness against” is an idiom that means to give a warning. Alternate translation: “I have warned you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been a witness against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “we will do it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: we will carry it out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fall” means to die. And “sword” represents the enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “Enemies will kill some of them and others will die of hunger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will fall by sword and famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I am opposed to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am setting against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “bend the bow” means to pull the string of the bow back with an arrow in order to shoot the arrow. Alternate translation: “skillful at shooting arrows from their bows” or “skillful with the bow and arrow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: skillful at bending their bows

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are saying that the nation of Egypt has become of little importance. The phrase “only a noise” is an idiom that means a person says he will do something but he does not do it. Alternate translation: “Pharaoh brags much but cannot do what he brags he will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Pharaoh the king of Egypt is only a noise, one who has let his opportunity slip away

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “stand together” is an idiom meaning to remain united. The writer is saying that the soldiers will not fight as a unit but will run away thinking only of saving themselves. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: They will not stand together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “this word came to” is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave this message to Jeremiah” or “Yahweh spoke this message to Jeremiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: This word came to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: A sword makes a noise as it slashes back and forth. Asking the sword to be silent means to ask it to stop slashing and killing. Alternate translation: “you rest” or “you stop slashing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you become silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth of a hole” is an idiom that means the entrance to a cave. Alternate translation: “the entrance to caves” or “an opening in the rocks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the mouth of a hole in the rocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “coming on you” is an idiom that means “to experience” something. Alternate translation: “You will experience the terror, the pit, and a trap” or “You will be terrified, and you will fall into pits and traps” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Terror and the pit, and a trap are coming on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “four winds from the four corners” is an idiom that represents wind blowing from every direction. Alternate translation: “I will cause the winds to blow from every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring the four winds from the four corners of the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “This is the message that Yahweh gave” or “This is the message that Yahweh spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the word that Yahweh declared

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is figurative language used to explain a spiritual connection to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: join ourselves to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stumble and fall” are idioms that refer to defeat and death. Alternate translation: “I will cause enemies to defeat and kill the proud ones” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the proud ones will stumble and fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “day of” is a Hebrew idiom for “when.” Alternate translation: “when I destroy Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “Call … to mind” and “come to mind” are idioms that mean to think about or remember. Alternate translation: “Though you are far away, think about Yahweh; think about Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Call Yahweh to mind from far away; let Jerusalem come to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: God implies that false gods should help the people who worship them. He knows that false gods cannot help people. When he said this he was using irony to show that he was angry that his people worshiped false gods. Alternate translation: “You do not ask them because know you that they cannot save you in your time of troubles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Let them arise if they wish to save you in your time of troubles

contextId.occurrenceNote: God appears to be praising his people for looking for love, but this is irony. He was showing that he was angry with them for being unfaithful to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: How well you make your way to look for love

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of how unfaithful his people are to him as though they were even teaching prostitutes how to be unfaithful to their husbands and find other men to be their lovers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: You have even taught your ways to wicked women

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an ironic statement emphasizing that none of their sacrifices were acceptable to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Go ahead and eat the burnt offerings along with your sacrifices and meat from them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and the meat from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is irony because the wise men are normally honored for their wisdom. Alternate translation: “Those men who think they are wise will feel ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: The wise men will be ashamed

contextId.occurrenceNote: “They do not grow strong on the earth because they are faithful to Yahweh, as they are wicked” and “This means that the people are not faithful to Yahweh, but rather are wicked and have gained their power through wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: but it is not because of any faithfulness of theirs that they grow strong on the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement is ironic because the examples about the Cushite and the leopard are impossible situations. This states that if those impossible things could happen then they could do good. Alternate translation: “Just like these things are impossible, so it is also impossible for you who always do evil to do good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: If so, then you yourself, although accustomed to wickedness, would be able to do good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Usually it is the sheep that are slaughtered, but here Yahweh says that he will slaughter the shepherds. The word “slaughter” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “for the time has come for me to slaughter you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: for the days of your slaughter have come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah uses irony to say that the “freedom” the people will enjoy will actually be suffering. Alternate translation: “I will proclaim misery to you … misery from the sword, the plague, and famine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to proclaim freedom to you & freedom for the sword, the plague, and famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an ironic statement. Yahweh does not really want them to fulfill their vow to a false goddess. Yahweh knows they will not listen to him so he tells them to go ahead and do what they want. Alternate translation: “Very well! If that is what you want to do, then go fulfill your vows and do what you promised to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Now fulfill your vows; carry them out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gilead was a region famous for having people skillful with medicine. Yahweh is mocking the Egyptians by telling them to go get medicine, but he knows it will not help them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up to Gilead and obtain medicine

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “from the least to the greatest” shows that all the people of Israel are included in the phrase “all of them,” regardless of how important they are. Alternate translation: “all of them, including the least powerful, the most powerful, and every one else, are greedy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: that from the least to the greatest, all of them are greedy

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “from the least to the greatest” shows that all the people of Judah are included in the phrase “all of them,” regardless of how important they are. Alternate translation: “because all of them, including the least powerful, the most powerful, and everyone else, are greedy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: because from the least to the greatest, all of them are greedy

contextId.occurrenceNote: By mentioning both “day” and “night” this phrase means all the time. Alternate translation: “all the time” or “continually” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: day and night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here two opposite times of the day are given to mean all the time. Alternate translation: “all the time, both night and day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: night and day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all kinds of people and uses size to refer to how important they are. Alternate translation: “Both the important and the unimportant” or “Many people, regardless of how important they are, will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Both the great and the small will

contextId.occurrenceNote: The mention of both “day” and “night” means all the time. Alternate translation: “all the time” or “continually” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: by day and night

contextId.occurrenceNote: By mentioning both ends of the earth, this phrase represents everywhere in between those ends. Alternate translation: “will on that day cover the entire earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: will on that day extend from one end of the earth to the other

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to every person, from the least important to the most important. Alternate translation: “every single one of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the smallest of them to the greatest

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to the whole of creation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the highest heavens & earth’s foundation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way to refer to people from every social status. Here “least” and “greatest” represent those who are least important and those who are most important. Alternate translation: “all the people from every social status” or “all the people, including the least important and the most important people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people from the least to the greatest

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people mention both extremes to emphasize that they will obey no matter what Yahweh’s answer is. Alternate translation: “Whatever he answers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Whether it is good or if it is bad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way to refer to people from every social status. Here “least” and “greatest” represent those who are least important and those who are most important. Alternate translation: “all the people from every social status” or “all the people, including the least important and the most important people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: From the least to the greatest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor representing Yahweh giving Jeremiah special authority to speak. Alternate translation: “Then it was as though Yahweh touched my mouth” or (2) Jeremiah was seeing a vision and Yahweh actually did this as a symbolic act of giving Jeremiah authority to speak. Alternate translation: “Then Yahweh touched my mouth with his hand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Then Yahweh reached out with his hand, touched my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase represents giving Jeremiah his message. Alternate translation: “I have given you my message for you to speak to the people” or “I have enabled you to tell the people my message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have placed my word in your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Jeremiah destroying the nations by what he says as if the nations were plants and he were to pull them up out of the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to uproot

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Jeremiah causing nations to become strong as if they were a building and he would build them, and as if they were plants and he would plant them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to build and plant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents guaranteeing that he will do what he has said. Alternate translation: “I am remembering my word to carry it out” or “I guarantee that I will do what I have said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am watching over my word to carry it out

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Disaster will be let loose from the north.” This represents God causing disaster to come from the north to the south. Alternate translation: “Disaster will come from the north” or “I will send disaster from the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Disaster will be opened up out of the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this represents ruling over Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “will rule at the gates of Jerusalem” or (2) this represents judging Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “will judge Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will set his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “be shattered” represents being extremely afraid, and “shatter” represents causing Jeremiah to be extremely afraid. Alternate translation: “Do not be terrified … I will terrify you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not be shattered & I will shatter you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being strong like these things represents being confident and unchanging in saying what God had told him to say. Alternate translation: “I have made you strong against the whole land like a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Today I have made you a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls against the whole land

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were the strongest materials known at that time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: iron & bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his relationship with the people of Israel as though they had been engaged to be married. Alternate translation: “when we first agreed that we would marry each other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when we were engaged

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel as if they were an offering dedicated to God. Alternate translation: “like the firstfruits of his harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the firstfruits of his harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of those who attacked Israel as if they were eating the offering that was set apart for God. Alternate translation: “All who attacked Israel were held guilty like people who ate from the first fruits of his harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: All who ate from the firstfruits were held guilty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “came upon them” is a metaphor for happened to them. Alternate translation: “Disasters happened to them” or “I made terrible things happen to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: disaster came upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents rejecting God and refusing to be loyal to him. Alternate translation: “they rejected me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they went far from following me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents choosing to be loyal to idols and worship them. Alternate translation: “they worshiped useless idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they went after useless idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “land of drought” is a land that does not have enough water. Here “deep darkness” is a metaphor for danger. Alternate translation: “a dangerous land where there is not enough water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a land of drought and deep darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “defiled” represents making the land unacceptable to God. They did this by sinning against him there when they worshiped idols. Alternate translation: “by sinning, you made my land no good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you defiled my land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) God is speaking of his land as if he had inherited it. Alternate translation: “my land” or (2) God is speaking of the land he gave to Israel as if he had given it to them as an inheritance. Alternate translation: “the land I gave you” or “the land I gave you as an inheritance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders are spoken of as if they were shepherds and the people who followed them were sheep. Alternate translation: “Their leaders sinned against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The shepherds transgressed against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walked after” represents obeying or worshiping. Alternate translation: “obeyed unprofitable things” or “worshiped unprofitable things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walked after unprofitable things

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of himself as if he were springs of living waters. Alternate translation: “have abandoned me, their springs of living waters” or “have abandoned me, who is like springs of living water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have abandoned the springs of living waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of false gods as if they were cisterns that people dig in order to get water. Alternate translation: “have gone to false gods, which are like cisterns they have dug for themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have dug out cisterns for themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “become plunder” represents being attacked and taken as captives to another country. Alternate translation: “So why has Israel been taken away as captives” or “So why have Israel’s enemies taken Israel away as captives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So why has he become plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel’s enemies attacking Israel as if the enemies were lions roaring and attacking Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Young lions roared against him & hey made a lot of noise

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are a metaphor for asking the Egyptian and Assyrian armies to help them. Alternate translation: “why ask the Egyptians to help you … Why ask the Assyrians to help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: why take the road to Egypt and drink the waters of Shihor & Why take the road to Assyria and drink the waters of the Euphrates River

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “broke your yoke” and “tore your fetters off you” are metaphors for setting them free from slavery. The people of Israel had been slaves in Egypt. Alternate translation: “Long ago I released you from slavery, but still you refused to worship me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For I broke your yoke that you had in ancient days; I tore your fetters off you & till you said, ‘I will not serve!’

contextId.occurrenceNote: What they bowed down to can be stated clearly. Here “adulterer” is a metaphor for someone who is unfaithful to God. Alternate translation: “You bowed down to idols and worshiped them instead of me, like an adulterous wife who is unfaithful to her husband” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: since you bowed down on every high hill and beneath every leafy tree, you adulterer

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of making his people into a great nation in Canaan as if they were the seed of a grapevine that he had planted. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, started you with a very good beginning, like a farmer who uses excellent seed to plant the best kind of vine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I planted you as a choice vine, completely from pure seed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for serving or worshiping. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walked after

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel worshiping other gods as if they were like a female camel running in different directions looking for a male camel to mate with. Alternate translation: “You are like a swift female camel running back and forth looking for a male camel to mate with” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you are a swift female camel running here and there

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel worshiping other gods as if they were a wild female donkey running to find male donkeys. Alternate translation: “You are like a young female donkey that lives in the desert. When she wants to mate she is out of control and constantly sniffs the breeze to find a mate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a wild donkey accustomed to the wilderness, in her heat sniffing the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel wanting to worship other gods as if they were running around in the desert looking for those gods. Alternate translation: “I have told you to stop running here and there chasing after false gods, because all that it does is wear out your sandals and make you very thirsty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You must restrain your feet from becoming bare and your throat from being thirsty!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “strangers” represents foreign gods, and “go after them” represents worshiping them. Alternate translation: “We must follow after foreign gods and worship them!’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: No, I love strangers and go after them!

contextId.occurrenceNote: “their backs are toward me; their faces are not toward me.” This represents them rejecting God. Alternate translation: “they have turned away from me” or “they have turned their backs toward me and not their faces” or “they have completely rejected me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their back faces me and not their faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “accept discipline” represents learning from discipline. Alternate translation: “They refused to learn from discipline” or “When I disciplined them, they refused to learn to obey me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They would not accept discipline

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the people of Israel killing the prophets as if their sword were a lion that ate the prophets. Alternate translation: “You have killed the prophets brutally with your sword like a destructive lion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your sword has devoured your prophets like a destructive lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “a wilderness” and “a land of deep darkness” are metaphors for danger. God uses this question to rebuke the Israelites for behaving as though he had been dangerous. Alternate translation: “You act as though I have been like a wilderness or a land of deep darkness to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have I been a wilderness to Israel? Or a land of deep darkness?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his people worshiping other gods as if they were a woman who is unfaithful to her husband and is looking for other men to love her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to look for love

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for being terribly unacceptable to God. Alternate translation: “completely unacceptable to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: greatly polluted

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel worshiping idols as if they were a woman who had sex with many different men. He uses this question to tell the Israelites that he knows that they have worshiped idols everywhere. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no place where you have not had illicit sex!” or “As a whore sleeps with many men, you have worshiped your idols everywhere!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is there any place where you have not had illicit sex?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his people being eager to worship any idol as being like a prostitute waiting by the road for any man to come along. Alternate translation: “Like a prostitutes waiting at the roadside for her lovers, you were eager to worship any idol you learned about” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: By the roadsides you sat waiting for your lovers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if Israel were a woman. Alternate translation: “Israel’s people have gone up” or “They have gone up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: She has gone up

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel and Judah as if they were sisters. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah, who also did not obey me, saw” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her faithless sister Judah saw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “defiled” represents making the land unacceptable to God. They did this by sinning against him there when they worshiped idols. Alternate translation: “she made my land no good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: she defiled the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “strangers” refers to foreign gods. God speaks of Israel worshiping foreign gods as if Israel were a woman who was having sex with strangers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have shared your ways with strangers under every leafy tree!

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel belonging to him as if he were Israel’s husband. Alternate translation: “you belong to me as a wife belongs to her husband” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am your husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God speaks of leaders as if they were shepherds and the people they led were sheep. Alternate translation: “I will give you leaders … they will lead you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give you shepherds & they will shepherd you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the people of Israel. The phrase “bear fruit” is a metaphor for having many descendants. Alternate translation: “you will increase greatly in number” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: you will increase and bear fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of people’s actions as if the people were walking along a path. Here the word “hearts” represents their minds or wills. Alternate translation: “They will no longer stubbornly do the wicked things that they want to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will no longer walk in the stubbornness of their wicked hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walk with” represents being united. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah will be united with the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah will walk with the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of giving them the land to possess forever as if it were an inheritance. Alternate translation: “the land that I gave to your ancestors so that it would belong to their descendants forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the land that I gave your ancestors as an inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the land he wanted to give to Israel as if it were an inheritance. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: an inheritance more beautiful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “have forgotten” represents neglecting or ignoring. Alternate translation: “They have ignored Yahweh their God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they have forgotten Yahweh their God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “heal you of treachery” represents causing Israel to stop being unfaithful to God. Alternate translation: “I will cause you to stop being unfaithful to me” or (2) “heal you of treachery” represents forgiving Israel for being unfaithful. Alternate translation: “I will forgive your treachery” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will heal you of treachery!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being fully aware of their shame is spoken of as if shame were covering them like a blanket or a garment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: May our shame cover us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “the time of our youthfulness” refers to when each person was young. Alternate translation: “from when we were young” or (2) “the time of our youthfulness” is a metaphor that refers to when Israel was first becoming a nation. Alternate translation: “from when we were first becoming a nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from the time of our youthfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “wander” is a metaphor for being unfaithful. Alternate translation: “if you remain faithful to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: do not wander from me again

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh tells the people to prepare their lives like a farmer prepares the ground for planting. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Plow your own ground, and do not sow among thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes the people’s devotion to him in terms of the physical sign of covenant. Alternate translation: “Dedicate yourselves completely to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Circumcise yourselves to Yahweh, and remove the foreskins of your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God sending an army from the north to cause disaster and destruction in Judah. Alternate translation: “for I will cause an army from the north to come and destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for I am bringing disaster from the north and a great collapse

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of a powerful army as if it were a fierce lion. Alternate translation: “A powerful and merciless army approaches” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A lion is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Anger is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could turn away from people. Here “Yahweh’s anger has not turned away from us” means that Yahweh is still very angry with the people. Alternate translation: “For Yahweh is still very angry with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the force of Yahweh’s anger has not turned away from us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a “burning wind” represents a fierce and merciless enemy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: burning wind from the plains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh shows his love for his people by speaking of them as a daughter. Alternate translation: “my people, who are like a daughter to me” or “my dear people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: far stronger than the “burning wind” of verse 11. The wind is a metaphor for a fierce and merciless enemy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A wind far stronger than that

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a warning to the people living in Jerusalem to repent. “Cleanse your heart” is a metaphor for removing evil from their lives. Alternate translation: “People of Jerusalem, stop being evil” or “People of Jerusalem, stop living wickedly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Cleanse your heart from wickedness, Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” probably refers to the emotions, and “strike your very heart” probably refers to causing them to suffer terribly. Alternate translation: “It will be as if it strikes your very heart” or “It will cause you to suffer terrible anguish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It will strike your very heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “turn” represents deciding not to do what he said he would do. Alternate translation: “I will not change my mind about doing what I said I would do” or “I will not refuse to do what I planned to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not turn from carrying them out

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the nations that Judah had depended on for wealth and business as if they were men who lusted after Judah. Those nations would reject Judah when they see God’s judgment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: men who lusted for you now reject you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God shows his love for the people of Jerusalem by speaking of them as a daughter. Alternate translation: “my dear daughter, Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: God punished his people in various ways. Here it is spoken of as if he hit them. Alternate translation: “You punish the people, but they do not pay attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You struck the people, but they do not feel pain.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “to receive discipline” represents learning from discipline to do what is right. Alternate translation: “they still refuse to learn their lesson” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they still refuse to receive discipline

contextId.occurrenceNote: The yoke and chains represent the law which bind God and his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: But they all broke their yoke together; they all tore apart the chains that bound them to God.
