contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh becoming angry and punishing the people of Judah is spoken of as his fury and wrath were a fire. Alternate translation: “my fury and wrath were like a fire” or “my punishment was like a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: kindled a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being separated from the people of Judah is spoken of as if the people are cut off from Judah the way a person may cut off a branch from a vine or cut off a piece of cloth. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Why are you causing me to remove you from the people of Judah … and babies?” or “You are causing me to remove you from the people of Judah … and babies.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Why are you causing yourselves to be cut off from among Judah & and babies?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Obeying the laws is spoken of as if it were walking in the laws. Alternate translation: “nor do they obey them” or “nor do you obey them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: nor do they walk in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing disaster to happen is spoken of as if disaster were an object that can be brought to someone. Alternate translation: “to cause disaster to happen to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to bring disaster to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Allowing Baruch to escape and remain alive is spoken of as if his life were plunder that he would take after a battle. Alternate translation: “but wherever you go, I will protect you and allow you to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your life as your plunder everywhere you will go

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing and killing his enemies is spoken of as if he would use a sword to kill them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The sword will devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh avenging himself by causing the Egyptians to lose in battle against the Babylonians is spoken of as if the Egyptian army would be a sacrifice to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “For the Egyptians will be like a sacrifice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For there will be a sacrifice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Egypt are spoken of as if they were the virgin daughter of Egypt. Alternate translation: “people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: virgin daughter of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Soldiers dying in battle is spoken of as if they were stumbling and falling down. Alternate translation: “for your soldiers die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for soldier stumbles against soldier; both of them fall together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nation of Egypt, which was very strong and prosperous, is spoken of as if it were a beautiful young cow. Alternate translation: “Egypt is like a very beautiful heifer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt is a very beautiful young cow

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy army coming to attack the Egyptians is spoken of as if the army were an insect that stings. Alternate translation: “but a powerful army like a stinging insect” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but a stinging insect

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a day as if it travels and arrives in a location. Alternate translation: “they will experience disaster on that day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of their disaster is coming against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues speaking of the enemy army attacking the Egyptians as if the army were woodcutters cutting down trees. Alternate translation: “The enemy army will kill many Egyptians like woodcutters cutting down a forest … even though there are very many trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will cut down the forests & although it is very dense

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Egypt are spoken of as if they were the daughter of Egypt. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemy army will humiliate the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The daughter of Egypt will be made ashamed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues speaking of the army from the north as an overflowing river. Alternate translation: “like an overflowing river, the army from the north will destroy the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will overflow the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a day as if it were something that travels and arrives in a place. Alternate translation: “For on that day, the enemy army will devastate all of the Philistines and cut off from Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the day is coming that will devastate all of the Philistines, to cut off from Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: Removing someone is spoken of as if they were cut off the way a person may cut a branch from a tree or a piece of cloth from a garment. Alternate translation: “to remove anyone who may want to help Tyre and Sidon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to cut off from Tyre and Sidon every survivor who wants to help them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing the Philistines by sending the army from the north is spoken of as if Yahweh were striking them with a sword. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: sword of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Helping the people is spoken of as if they would put wings on the people so that could fly away. Alternate translation: “Help the people of Moab to escape as if you were giving them wings to fly away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Give wings to Moab, for she must certainly fly away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy army defeating the people of Moab and taking them as captives is spoken of as if the people of Moab are wine and someone will come and pour them out and break the wine jars. Alternate translation: “I will send an army that will destroy them as if they were pouring out wine and breaking the jars” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send him those who will tip him over and pour out all his pots and shatter his jars

contextId.occurrenceNote: The best men of Moab going to battle and being killed is spoken of as if they were animals taken to a place to be slaughtered. Alternate translation: “their fine young men will all be slaughtered” or “the enemy army will kill all of the finest men of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: its finest young men have gone down to the place of slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something terrible happening soon is spoken of as if calamity were something that could move quickly to a place. Alternate translation: “terrible things will happen very soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: calamity is hurrying quickly

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Dibon are spoken of as if they were the daughter of Dibon. Alternate translation: “you people living in Dibon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you daughter living in Dibon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people experiencing Yahweh’s punishment is spoken of as if they were drunk on wine, acting foolishly so that people laugh at them. Alternate translation: “I will cause you to be like a drunk person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Make him drunk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues speaking of the people of Moab as if they were a drunk person. Alternate translation: “Now the people of Moab will be like a person who wallows in his vomit … an object of ridicule (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Let Moab wallow in his vomit & an object of ridicule

contextId.occurrenceNote: The town of Sibmah had many vineyards. Here, Yahweh speaks to the people of Sibmah as if there were a grapevine. Alternate translation: “people of Sibmah, who are like a grapevine with branches that passed … your wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: vine of Sibmah! Your branches passed & your wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues speaking of the people of Sibmah as if they were a grapevine. Alternate translation: “The destroyers have attacked you and have taken the fruit from your vineyards and your wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The destroyers have attacked your summer fruit and your wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing an army to attack is spoken of as if he would sound the signal for the battle to start. Alternate translation: “when I will cause the enemy army to sound the signal for battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I will sound the signal for battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “daughters” represent the women who live in Rabbah. Alternate translation: “women of Rabbah” or (2) all the people in general are spoken of as if they are the daughters of Rabbah. Alternate translation: “people of Rabbah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: daughters of Rabbah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the people of Ammon are spoken of as if they were a daughter. Alternate translation: “faithless people” or “rebellious people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: faithless daughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing an enemy army to come and take everything is spoken of as if Yahweh stripped all the clothes off of Esau. Alternate translation: “But I have sent an army to take everything away from Esau” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: But I have stripped Esau bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues speaking of Yahweh punishing the people of Edom as if he would come like a lion and attack the sheep. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He will drag them away, even the smallest flock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They will certainly be dragged away, even the smallest flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the youngest and weakest people of Edom are spoken of as if they are the smallest flock of sheep. Alternate translation: “even the weakest and the smallest people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: even the smallest flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the land of Edom is spoken of as if it were pasturelands for flocks. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He will turn their pasturelands into ruined places” or “He will completely get rid of the people who live there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Their pasturelands will be turned into ruined places

contextId.occurrenceNote: The loud sound of Edom being destroyed is spoken of as if Edom were a large object that shakes the earth when it falls. Alternate translation: “When enemies come and destroy Edom, the noise will be extremely loud, with the result that the earth will shake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: At the sound of their falling the earth shakes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being afraid is spoken of as if the person were melting. Alternate translation: “They are very afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They melt away

contextId.occurrenceNote: They young men being killed is spoken of as if they will fall. Alternate translation: “enemies will kill the young men of Damascus in its plazas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: its young men will fall in its plazas

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “every wind” represents the nations. Alternate translation: “Then I will send to nations in all different directions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Then I will scatter to every wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “winds” represents nations. And the nations are a synecdoche representing the armies from those nations. Causing armies to come from all directions is spoken of as if Yahweh will cause wind to blow from all directions Alternate translation: “I will bring your enemies from every direction to attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring the four winds from the four corners of the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “winds” represents “nations.” Alternate translation: “to all those nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to all of those winds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Seeking a person’s life represents wanting or desiring to kill someone. Alternate translation: “those who want to kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: those who seek their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing people to experience disaster is spoken of as if he would bring disaster against them. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to experience disaster” or “I will cause terrible things to happen to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring disaster against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Seeking **Yahweh their God** represents either: (1) asking God for help or (2) thinking about God and obeying him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: seek Yahweh their God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a group of sheep that was lost. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “My people have been like a lost flock of sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: My people have been a lost flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders of Israel are spoken of as if they were the shepherds of people. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “Their leaders were like shepherds who” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Their shepherds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Attacking the people of Israel is spoken of as if a wild animal ate them. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “devoured them like a wild animal would eat its prey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: devoured them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as the source of their trust. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **hope**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “the one whom their ancestors confidently expected to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh, the hope of their ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Israel as if it were a sheep that was trying to escape from hungry lions. This metaphor can be stated as a simile and in active form. Alternate translation: “Israel is like a sheep that lions scattered and drove away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel is a sheep scattered and driven away by lions

contextId.occurrenceNote: The destruction of Israel by Assyria is spoken of as if Israel were a sheep that Assyria ate. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: devoured him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The destruction of Israel by Nebuchadnezzar is spoken of if it were a sheep which had its bones crushed by a lion. Alternate translation: “destroyed Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: broke his bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel is spoken of as if they were sheep that eat grass. Alternate translation: “they will eat food that grows in Carmel and Bashan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will graze on Carmel and Bashan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The army of Babylon is spoken of as if it were a hammer. The destruction of this army is spoken of as if the hammer was to be cut up and destroyed. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “The mighty army of Babylon that conquered all the nations is like a hammer that will be broken into pieces and destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: How the hammer of all the lands has been cut apart and destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The destruction of Babylon is spoken of as if Yahweh had caught them in a trap like an animal. Alternate translation: “I set a trap and caught you in it as a hunter catches an animal” or “You people of Babylon, I have set a trap for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have set a trap for you and you were taken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “granaries” represent where Babylon stored its treasures. Alternate translation: “Raid the places where her treasures are stored” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Open her granaries

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the word **bulls** could mean: (1) soldiers or (2) strong young men. Killing them is spoken of as taking them to a place of slaughter. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Kill all her bulls & end them down to the place of slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The evil things the Babylonians did to Israel are spoken of as if Babylon measured them. Alternate translation: “Measure out punishment for her with the same amount she used to punish Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do to her by the measure she has used

contextId.occurrenceNote: Fire burning the cities of Babylon is spoken of as if the fire were an animal that ate them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour everything around him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a lawyer who represents the people of Israel in court. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will truly plead their case

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being “stirred up” represents being urged to take action. Alternate translation: “are preparing to come from the most distant places on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: are being stirred up from the farthest parts of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Feeling great anguish is spoken of as if anguish grabs the king of Babylon. Alternate translation: “He felt terrible anguish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Anguish seized him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues speaking of Yahweh punishing the people of Babylon as if he would come like a lion and attack the sheep. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He will drag them away, even the smallest flock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They will certainly be dragged away, even the smallest flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the youngest and weakest people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the smallest flock of sheep. Alternate translation: “even the youngest and weakest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: even the smallest flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the land of Babylonia is spoken of as if it were pasturelands for flocks. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He will turn their pasturelands into ruined places” or “He will completely destroy the people who live there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Their pasturelands will be turned into ruined places

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares the fall of the once powerful nation of Babylon to the extremely loud noise of an earthquake. Alternate translation: “The fall of Babylon will sound like a mighty earthquake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: At the sound of conquered Babylon the earth shakes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her,” a metaphor that refers to Babylon as if it were a woman, is also a metonym for the people who live in Babylon. Alternate translation: “separate the people who live there from each other, send them in different directions, and make their land empty … foreigners will attack the people of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: scatter her and devastate her land & they will come against her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land in which they live is spoken of as if it were a container and their offenses as if they were solid objects that could fill the container. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **offenses**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “they have offended the Holy One of Israel everywhere throughout the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: their land is filled with offenses committed against the Holy One of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon is spoken of as if it were a woman. The word “iniquity” is a metonym for God punishing the people for their iniquity. Alternate translation: “when Yahweh punishes Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in her iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon is spoken of as if it were a woman, and the iniquity of the people is spoken of as if Yahweh needed to pay back a debt. The word “her,” meaning Babylon, is a metonym for the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: “will punish the Babylonians as much as they deserve” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will repay all of it to her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “world” is a metonym for the people living in the nations surrounding Babylon. This could mean: (1) Making those people drunk could be a metaphor for Yahweh punishing those nations by allowing Babylon to conquer them. Alternate translation: “Babylon was a strong nation that Yahweh used to punish all the people of the surrounding nations severely” or (2) It could be a metaphor for those nations joining Babylon in worshiping idols and being violent. Alternate translation: “Babylon was a rich and powerful nation, and other nations wanted to become sinful just like it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon was a golden cup in the hand of Yahweh that made all the world drunk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon being a powerful nation that Yahweh used for his own purposes is spoken of as if Babylon were a golden cup in his hand. Here “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon was a golden cup in the hand of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “Babylon defeated and destroyed other nations” or (2) “nations enjoyed her riches and power and became evil.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: nations drank her wine and became insane

contextId.occurrenceNote: Guilt is spoken of as if it were an object that could be made into a pile. The words “to the heavens” and “to the clouds” are an exaggeration for something that is very high. Alternate translation: “For Babylon is so very guilty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: For her guilt reaches up to the heavens; it is piled up to the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people’s lives are spoken of as if they were threads that God could cut. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Your lives will be ended quickly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The thread of your life is now cut short

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases compare the voice of Yahweh to the loud sound made by thunder and rain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When he thunders, there is the roar of waters in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Israel belonging to Yahweh as if it were something that Yahweh gained through inheritance. Alternate translation: “The tribe of Israel belongs to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel is the tribe of his inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of punishing people as if he were smashing them with a hammer. Alternate translation: “With you I will punish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: With you I will smash

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stops speaking of Babylon as a mountain and speaks of it as a building that he is breaking down and throwing away. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will & roll you down from the cliffs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Babylon as no longer being the great “mountain of destruction” but now a mountain that he has destroyed. Alternate translation: “I will … make you a pile of useless rocks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will & make you a burned-out mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “the homes in the city are on fire, the bars of the city gates are broken” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her homes are on fire, the bars of her gates are broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing the daughter of Babylon is spoken of as if he were trampling and threshing grain on a threshing floor. Alternate translation: “It is time to punish her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It is time to trample her down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The harvest is a metaphor for the result of the actions that the people did before. Babylon will experience the result of its people’s sins. Alternate translation: “God will punish her for her sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the time of harvest will come to her

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The speaker speaks as if he were a woman. The woman is a metaphor for the city of Jerusalem, which in turn is a metonym for the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon has taken everything from Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: has made me an empty pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem compares its destruction to being swallowed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has swallowed me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues to speak of Babylon as if it were a monster. This states in another way the previous idea that Babylon has taken everything from Israel. Here “foods” represents all the good things that were there before. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he has filled his stomach with my delicious foods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar took what he wanted and spit out what he did not want. Alternate translation: “he has vomited me up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has spit me out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh defending his people is spoken of as if he were a lawyer pleading their case in court. Alternate translation: “I will be like your lawyer to defend you and I will bring about vengeance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to plead your case and bring about vengeance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon’s enemies have overcome her. “Waves” represent many people groups overcoming Babylon. The words “sea” and “water” often represent the nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The sea & roaring waves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The many nations that come to Babylon to sacrifice to Bel is spoken of as a river that moves along. Alternate translation: “the people of other nations will no longer come in large groups” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations will no longer flow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Removing the idols of Babylon is spoken of as if Yahweh would punish the idols. Alternate translation: “I will remove the carved idols of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will punish the carved idols of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speakers’ reaction to people expressing disapproval of them is spoken of as if it were a cover placed over the speakers’ faces. Alternate translation: “our faces show that we are hurt because others disapprove of us” or “we cover our faces in shame because others disapprove of us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: reproach has covered our faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Removing or destroying idols is spoken of as if Yahweh would punish the idols. Alternate translation: “I will destroy her carved idols” or “I will remove her carved idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will punish her carved idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh’s judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what was evil in Yahweh’s judgment” or “what Yahweh considers to be evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The surface refers to the surface of the water in the pot. Jeremiah could see the water boiling. Alternate translation: “whose water is boiling” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: whose surface is churning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Setting their thrones “against all the walls that surround it” represents commanding their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “and they will command their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against all the walls that surround it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Setting their thrones “against all the cities of Judah” represents commanding their armies to destroy all the cities of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against all the cities of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents all the people of the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the whole land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob’s descendants. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel’s descendants, who had become the nation of Israel. Alternate translation: “the Israelites” or “the Israelite people group” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to God himself, who is glorious. Alternate translation: “their glorious God” or “me, your glorious God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here false gods are spoken of in terms of what they cannot do. Alternate translation: “for false gods, which cannot help” or “for gods who cannot help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for what cannot help

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “born in his master’s home” is metonym for being born into slavery. Alternate translation: “Was he born a slave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Was he born in his master’s home

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents destroying the land in such a way that people will feel horror when they see it. Alternate translation: “destroyed Israel’s land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: made his land a horror

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tree” and “stone” represent idols carved from wood and stone. These words emphasize that the idol was made of ordinary things and is not worthy of worship. Alternate translation: “These people are the ones who say to a carved piece of wood, ‘You are my father,’ and to a carved stone, ‘You gave birth to me.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the ones who say to the tree, ‘You are my father,’ and to the stone, ‘You gave birth to me.’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “judgment” represents punishment. Alternate translation: “I will punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring down judgment on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “your eyes” represents looking at something. Alternate translation: “Look up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift up your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The arrogance showing on a person’s face is spoken of as if the face itself were arrogant. Alternate translation: “But the expression on your face shows that you arrogant, like the face of a prostitute” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you have the forehead of a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stones” and “trees” represent the stone and wood material that was used to create idols. The people’s idol worship is spoken of as if they were committing adultery. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: she committed adultery with stones and trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the north represents the people of Israel who had been taken north to Assyria. Alternate translation: “Go and proclaim these words to the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Go and proclaim these words to the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents Yahweh’s desire or will. The phrase “after my heart” is an idiom that describes people who do God’s will. Alternate translation: “shepherds who do my will” or “shepherds who do what I want” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: shepherds after my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “come up in their hearts” represents thinking about it. Alternate translation: “They will no longer think of this matter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This matter will no longer come up in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Yahweh’s throne” represents the place from where Yahweh rules. Alternate translation: “This is from where Yahweh rules” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This is Yahweh’s throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: “Judah” or “the kingdom of Judah” or “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Israel” or “the kingdom of Israel” or “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the hills” represent the people’s worship of false gods on the hills. The people now realize that those false gods could not guide and help them. Alternate translation: “The false gods that we worshiped on the hills could not guide us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Surely lies come from the hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “listened” represents obeying, and “the voice of Yahweh” represents what Yahweh has said. Alternate translation: “have not obeyed what Yahweh our God has said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: have not listened to the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a command that emphasizes who they should return to. Alternate translation: “then come back to me” or “then worship me” (2) this is a repetition of the first phrase, which expresses a condition. Alternate translation: “if you will come back to me” or “if you will start worshiping me again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: then it should be to me that you return

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “detestable things” refers to idols, which God hates. Alternate translation: “If you remove your disgusting idols from my presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: If you remove your detestable things from before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the nations” is a metonym for people of other nations. The word “him” refers to Yahweh. Since Yahweh is speaking, it can also be translated as “me.” Alternate translation: “people of other nations will bless themselves in me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations will bless themselves in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bless themselves in him” is a metonym for asking Yahweh to bless them. Alternate translation: “the people of the nations will ask Yahweh to bless them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations will bless themselves in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents an enemy army that would come from the north. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents destroying the land, which would cause people who see it to be horrified. Alternate translation: “to destroy your land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to bring horror to your land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hearts” represent courage. Also “the hearts … will die” represents losing courage and being afraid. Alternate translation: “the king and his officials will stop being courageous” or “the king and his officials will be terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the hearts of the king and his officials will die

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents painful emotions, such as grief and fear. The phrase is repeated to express the intensity of the pain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: My heart! My heart!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” represents the people living in the city. Alternate translation: “The people of every city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Every city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “scarlet” represents expensive, red clothing. Alternate translation: “you wear expensive red clothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you dress in scarlet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “trying to take your life away” represents trying to kill the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “They are trying to kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they are trying to take away your life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hard faces represents the expression on their faces that shows that they are stubborn. The simile “harder than rock” shows that the people are extremely stubborn. Alternate translation: “They are extremely stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They make their faces harder than rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for a person’s descendants. In this case it refers to the people of the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. Alternate translation: “For the people of Israel and Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For the houses of Israel and Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “prophets” is a metonym that represents what the prophets say, and “wind” is a metaphor for something that does not do anything. Alternate translation: “The prophets words are just noisy wind” or “The prophets make noise like the wind, but what they prophesy will not happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The prophets will become wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Its quiver” represents the enemy nation’s army, and the arrows in the quiver represent the soldiers in the army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Its quiver & They are all soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cannot see” is a metonym for not understanding. Alternate translation: “you do not understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you cannot see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cannot hear” represents not understanding. “Alternate translation: “you do not understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you cannot hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “wickedness” represents disaster and the people who will cause it. Alternate translation: “enemies will come from the north and cause disaster to happen to you” or “enemies coming from the north will destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: wickedness is appearing from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of kings leading their armies to destroy the land, as if they were shepherds leading their sheep to eat grass. Alternate translation: “like a shepherd each king will lead his army” or “each king will lead his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: each man will shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The end of the day is spoken of in terms of its light becoming dark. Alternate translation: “the day is ending” or “it is beginning to get dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the daylight is fading away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God speaks to the people of Jerusalem as if he were speaking to the city itself. Alternate translation: “Accept discipline, you people of Jerusalem … make your land into a ruin, an uninhabited land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Accept discipline, Jerusalem & make you into a ruin, an uninhabited land

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Accept discipline” here is a metaphor for learning from discipline. Alternate translation: “Learn from your discipline” or “When I punish you, learn to do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Accept discipline

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences are telling the people of other nations to witness what Yahweh will do to the rebellious people of Judah. Alternate translation: “Therefore, you people of other nations, listen! You witnesses, see what will happen to my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore, nations, listen! See, you witnesses, what will happen to them.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “swords of the enemy” represents the enemy with their swords ready to attack. Here, **terror** refers to things that cause people to be frightened. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **terror**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “For the enemy is everywhere with their swords and everyone else is terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: for the swords of the enemy and terror are all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here pouring out innocent blood represents killing those not deserving death. Alternate translation: “kill innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: pour out innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here walking after is a metonym for following after with the intent to serve and obey. Alternate translation: “serve other gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: walk after other gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh’s temple. It can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “house that belongs to me” or “temple where you worship me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: house that is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here listening to Yahweh’s voice means to both hear his words and obey what he says. Alternate translation: “Hear and obey what I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sons of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “detestable things” refers to idols, which God hates. Alternate translation: “their disgusting idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their detestable things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “mind” refers to Yahweh’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “nor did I ever think about it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: nor did it enter my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for what happens at marriage ceremonies. Alternate translation: “and people celebrating marriage” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sound of the groom and the sound of the bride

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pen represents the words that the scribes write. Alternate translation: “The false things that the scribes write” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The deceitful pen of the scribes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people’s speech is represented by their “mouths.” Alternate translation: “They speak, saying that they want peace with their neighbors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: With their mouths they proclaim peace with their neighbors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s “voice” represents what he says. Alternate translation: “they do not pay attention to the things I tell them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they do not listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people’s “stubborn hearts” represent their stubborn desires and stubborn will. Also, here “walked” represents living. Alternate translation: “they have been stubborn and lived the way they want to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they have walked by their stubborn hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” refers to an enemy army. Alternate translation: “I will send an army of soldiers to fight against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send out a sword after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh causing the people’s enemies to destroy them. Alternate translation: “I have caused their enemies to completely destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have completely destroyed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “send out for” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Send people out to get women who are skilled at mourning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Send out for women skilled at lamenting

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” refers to the people who live in these places. Foreigners being uncircumcised was a sign that they were not in Yahweh’s covenant. Alternate translation: “For the people of these nations did not enter into a covenant with Yahweh through circumcision” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For all these nations are uncircumcised

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “heart” represents a person’s will and desires. An “uncircumcised heart” represents the character of a person that does not follow Yahweh and his laws. Also, the “house” of Israel refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “all the people of Israel are only circumcised on the outside and have not changed their hearts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: all the house of Israel has an uncircumcised heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “house” of Israel represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s “name” refers to himself and his reputation. Alternate translation: “you are very powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your name is great in power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is represented by his “voice” to emphasize his speech. The phrase “the roar of waters” refers to loud storms. Alternate translation: “His voice causes the storms in the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: His voice makes the roar of waters in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents the people of Israel. God being their “portion” is an idiom that means that they worship him. Alternate translation: “the portion of Israel” or “whom the people of Israel worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the portion of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “voice” here is a metonym for what the speaker says with the voice, and “listen” is a metonym for “obey.” Alternate translation: “Obey what I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “voice” here is a metonym for what the speaker says with the voice, and “listen” is a metonym for “obey.” Alternate translation: “Obey what I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “cities of Judah” represents the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “The people who live in the cities of Judah and in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The cities of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart is a metonym for what a person feels and desires and “the mind” is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides. Alternate translation: “a person’s feelings and thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the heart and the mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents battle. Alternate translation: “will die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouths” represents what a person says. And, “hearts” represents what a person thinks or feels. Also, being loyal is spoken of as if it were being near a person, and being disloyal is spoken of as if it were being far away from a person. Alternate translation: “They always say good things about you, but they do not love or respect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You are near to them in their mouths, but far away from their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” represents a person’s thoughts and true feelings. Alternate translation: “my thoughts” or “my inner feelings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents control. Alternate translation: “to be conquered by her enemies” or “over to the control of her enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hands of her enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “shepherds” refers to their sheep. Alternate translation: “Many shepherds have allowed their sheep to destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Many shepherds have destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Judah and Jerusalem refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “of the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the throne that the king of Judah sits on is represented as “David’s throne.” Alternate translation: “the kings who sit on Judah’s throne” or “the kings of the nation of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the kings who sit on David’s throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” represents the people who live there. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemies will take all of the people of Judah captive into exile” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: All Judah will be taken captive, completely taken captive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “Let the people of Judah mourn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Let Judah mourn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s “name” refers to his reputation. Alternate translation: “for the sake of your reputation” or “in order that everyone can see that you are very great and keep your promises” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for the sake of your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here war is represented by the “sword” which was the common weapon used in battle. Alternate translation: “by war” or “by battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents war, and to “see” represents experiencing. Alternate translation: “You will not experience any war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not see the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to speaking with Yahweh’s power and authority or as his representative. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “there will be no war … perish by war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there will be no sword & perish by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “famine and war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: famine and sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “diseases” represent the people who have these diseases because of their starvation. Alternate translation: “there are the ones who are sick because of famine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there are the diseases that are caused by famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s “name” refers to his reputation. Alternate translation: “For the sake of your reputation” or “In order that everyone can see that you are very great and keep your promises” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For the sake of your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s “throne” is represented by Zion, that is Jerusalem. His “throne” also represents the place where he rules as king. Alternate translation: “do disgrace Zion where you glorious throne is” or “do not disgrace Zion, where you rule as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your glorious throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents war. To be “for the sword” means that God has appointed them to die in war. Alternate translation: “those whom I have appointed to die in war should go to die in war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: those who are for the sword should go to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” refers to the enemy soldiers. Alternate translation: “the enemy soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “for you people who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for you, Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power. Alternate translation: “I will use my power to strike you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents the enemy soldiers. This means that Yahweh will allow the enemy solider to kill any of her children that remain. Alternate translation: “I will allow the enemy soldiers to kill those of her children that remain alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give those who remain to the sword in the presence of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” represents a person emotions and feelings. Alternate translation: “what I love most” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the delight of my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents control. Alternate translation: “the control of the wicked … the control of the tyrant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the wicked & the hand of the tyrant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “cup” represents the drink that the cup holds. Alternate translation: “none must give a comforting drink” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: none must give a comforting cup

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “nations” represents the people from the nations. Alternate translation: “The people from the nations will go to you” or “The people of the nations will come to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.quoteString: The nations will go to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “deceit” refers to false gods. Alternate translation: “our ancestors inherited nothing but false gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: our ancestors inherited deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to power and authority. The two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh’s great power. Alternate translation: “my great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my hand and my power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” refers to Yahweh’s entire person. Alternate translation: “they will know that I am Yahweh, the true God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will know that Yahweh is my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “flesh” represents humans. Alternate translation: “he depends on mere humans for strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he makes flesh his strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the thoughts and emotions. Alternate translation: “turns his devotion away from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: turns his heart away from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the minds and thoughts of people. Alternate translation: “The human mind is more deceitful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The heart is more deceitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hearts” represents the emotions. Alternate translation: “who tests the emotions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who tests the hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents sight and sight represents one’s opinion. Alternate translation: “that he thought was good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that was pleasing in his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “it” refers to a nation or kingdom, which is a metonym for the people in that nation or kingdom. The word “eyes” represents seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “if the people of that nation do things that I consider to be evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: if it does evil in my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “voice” represents the words that Yahweh speaks. Here, “not listening” is an idiom that means that they do not obey. Alternate translation: “not obeying what I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: not listening to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the person’s mind or will. Alternate translation: “what his evil, stubborn mind desires” or “whatever evil things that we stubbornly want to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: what his evil, stubborn heart desires

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “fury” represents the punishment that Yahweh intended to inflict upon them. Jeremiah speaks of Yahweh not punishing them as if he were turning his fury away from them. Alternate translation: “so that you would not punish them in your anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to cause your fury to turn away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents power. Alternate translation: “cause those who use the sword to have power over them” or “cause them to die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: give them to the hands of those who use the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “innocent blood” represents the murder of innocent people. Yahweh speaks of murdering many people as filling a place with blood. Alternate translation: “murdered many innocent people in this place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: filled this place with innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) that Pashhur himself beat Jeremiah or (2) that Pashhur ordered other men to beat Jeremiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Pashhur beat Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to power. Alternate translation: “I will enable the king of Babylon to conquer all of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give all of Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Placing things in people’s hands represents giving thing to the people or allowing the people to take the things. Alternate translation: “I will give these things to your enemies” or “I will allow your enemies to take possession of these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will place these things in the hand of your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “word” refers to the message of Yahweh. The words “reproach” and “mocking” can be translated with verbal phrases. Alternate translation: “people reproach and mock me every day because I proclaim Yahweh’s message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s word has become for me reproach and mocking every day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “I will never mention Yahweh or say anything about him” or (2) the word “name” represents authority. Alternate translation: “I will no longer speak as his messenger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not speak any longer in his name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mind” is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides, and the word “heart” is a metonym for what a person feels and desires. Alternate translation: “know every person’s thoughts and feelings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: see the mind and the heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents power. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those whom evildoers oppress with their power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: those who are oppressed from the hand of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the instruments of war refers to the soldiers who carry them and “hand” represents control. Alternate translation: “the soldiers that you command” or (2) the instruments of war are literal weapons and “your hand” represent both the king and his soldiers. Alternate translation: “the weapons that you and your soldiers carry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the instruments of war that are in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this refers to the battle in which swords are used. Alternate translation: “the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to the power of their enemies over them. Alternate translation: “into the power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metonym for death in battle. Alternate translation: “in battle” or (2) they will be killed by literal swords. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with the edge of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Death by the sword refers to death in battle. Alternate translation: “in battle and by famine and plague” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sword, famine, and plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents the power of the king to destroy the city. Alternate translation: “into the power of the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to king and his family. Alternate translation: “the king of Judah and his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the same people as “the house of the king of Judah.” All of the kings of Judah were descendants of David. Alternate translation: “Descendants of David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: House of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power. Alternate translation: “the power of the one who oppresses them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the hand” refers to power or control. Alternate translation: “the power of the oppressor” or “the one who would harm him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The metonym “throne” refers to kingly authority like David had. Alternate translation: “kings, ruling like David before them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: kings sitting on David’s throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym that describes the kings as powerful and wealthy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: riding in a chariot and on horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to the royal palace where the king lived or (2) “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, who were the royal line of the kings of Judah. Alternate translation: “the royal dynasty of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jehoahaz (verse 11) and his family. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” is a metonym for seeing and “heart” is a metonym for thinking. Alternate translation: “you never look for or think about anything except … crushing of others” or “you only look for and think about ways to cheat others and pour out innocent blood, and to oppress and crush others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there is nothing in your eyes and heart except worry & crushing of others

contextId.occurrenceNote: Listening is a metonym for obeying. Alternate translation: “you have not obeyed me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you have not listened to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: A signet ring was used by a king to place his seal of authority on documents. The signet ring therefore represents authority to rule. The right hand also represents authority to rule. Alternate translation: “the signet ring on my right hand that represented my authority to be king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the signet on my right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “hand” represents power and control. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the hand of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on a throne is a metonym for ruling as king. Alternate translation: “become king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sit on David’s throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” refers to the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “for all the people in the nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” refers to the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah will be rescued” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah will be rescued

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Israel” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel will live in security” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel will live in security

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of his heart being broken and his bones trembling because he is afraid of the judgment that will result from the lies of the false prophets. Alternate translation: “I have great fear for what will happen because of the false prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Regarding the prophets, my heart is broken in me, and all of my bones tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here trembling is associated with fear. Alternate translation: “I am very afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of my bones tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “minds” refers to the thoughts of the false prophets. Alternate translation: “visions that they imagined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: visions from their own minds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth” refers to what Yahweh said. Alternate translation: “not what Yahweh said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: not from Yahweh’s mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart’s intentions” refers to the things that Yahweh wanted to happen. Alternate translation: “completed and accomplished all the punishment that he had planned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: carried out and brought into being his heart’s intentions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” refers to the whole being of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “forget me … forgot me” or “forget who I am … forgot who I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: forget my name & forgot my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Baal’s name” refers to the god Baal. Alternate translation: “leading my people to worship Baal instead of me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in favor of Baal’s name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tongues” is a metonym for the ability to speak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who use their tongues

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” is a metonym for the family that lives inside it. Alternate translation: “his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “set my eyes” means he will see them. Seeing them is a metonym for caring for them. Alternate translation: “I will bless them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set my eyes on them for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” refers to war or enemy armies. Alternate translation: “I will send enemy armies” or “I will send out war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send out sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” represents the people of the nations. Yahweh speaks of people experiencing his fury as if they were to drink the wine that is in the cup. Alternate translation: “make all the people of the nations … drink the wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make all the nations & drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “because of the wars that I am causing to happen among them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: before the sword that I am sending out among them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” represents the people of the nations. Alternate translation: “I made all the people of the nations … drink the wine from the cup” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I made all the nations & drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” represents the people of the nations. Alternate translation: “People from other nations also had to drink the wine from the cup” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Other nations also had to drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the cup” is a metonym for the wine that it contains. Alternate translation: “all of these people had to drink the wine from the cup in Yahweh’s hand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of them had to drink the cup from Yahweh’s hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “before the wars that I am causing to happen among you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: before the sword that I am sending among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Jerusalem and can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the city that I have called by my name” or “Jerusalem, which I have called by my name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the city that is called by my name
