contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” represents war. Yahweh speaks of declaring war against the people as if he were calling a sword against them. Alternate translation: “I am declaring war against all the inhabitants of the land” or “I am bringing war against all the inhabitants of the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am calling a sword against all the inhabitants of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym for heaven. Alternate translation: “from heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the heights

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “flesh” represents humanity. Alternate translation: “on all mankind” or “on all people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: on all flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: What Yahweh would turn the city into is a metonym for what people would use the city for. Alternate translation: “I will make this city so that people will ask me to destroy others the way I have destroyed this city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn this city into a curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a metonym for violent death, and to bring blood on someone is to make them guilty of violent death. Alternate translation: “you are making yourselves and this city and its inhabitants guilty of the violent death of an innocent person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you are bringing innocent blood on yourselves and on this city and its inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ear is a metonym for what the ear hears. Alternate translation: “for you to hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person’s name is a metonym for his authority. Alternate translation: “with the authority of Yahweh our God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in the name of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is a metonym for the people who live there. Alternate translation: “all the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “city” and “land” are metonyms for the people who live there. Alternate translation: “prophesied that bad things would happen to the people who lived in this city and this land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: prophesied against this city and this land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. Ahikam was not a soldier, so he probably was able to talk to people and change their minds. Alternate translation: “Ahikam … was able to help Jeremiah” or “Ahikam … was able to keep the people from harming Jeremiah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of Ahikam & was with Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Ahikam did not allow the people to have the power to put Jeremiah to death” or “the people could not kill Jeremiah because Ahikam did not give them the power to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he was not given into the hand of the people to be put to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises, and the word “lands” is a metonym for the people who live in those lands. Alternate translation: “I … am putting the people who live in all these lands under the power of Nebuchadnezzar … servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I & am giving all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar & servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “him” refers to Nebuchadnezzar who represents the kingdom of Babylon. Alternate translation: “will defeat Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: subdue him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand here could be a metonym for Nebuchadnezzar’s power, or it could be a metonym for Nebuchadnezzar’s armies. Alternate translation: “I have used Nebuchadnezzar’s power to destroy it” or “I have enabled Nebuchadnezzar’s armies to destroy i” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have destroyed it by his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in my name” represents speaking with Yahweh’s power and authority or as his representative. Here these prophets claim that they received their message from Yahweh, but that had not. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **deceit**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “deceiving.” Alternate translation: “they say they are speaking for me when they prophesy, but they are deceiving you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: they are prophesying deceit in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nation” is a metonym for the people of that nation. Alternate translation: “the people of every nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: every nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The peace of the city is a metonym for the people living in peace. Alternate translation: “Do everything you can so the people of the city live in peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Seek the peace of the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Praying is spoken of as calling out with a loud voice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will call to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wanting to know what Yahweh requires is spoken of as trying to find where Yahweh is. Alternate translation: “you will want to do what I require you to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will seek me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for ruling as king. Alternate translation: “the king who rules the Israelites as David did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king who sits on the throne of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for war. The sword, famine, and disease are spoken of as people who can obey Yahweh’s command to harm the Israelites. Alternate translation: “I am going to punish them by having them die in war, from hunger, and from illness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to send sword, famine, and disease on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” is a metonym for the person. Alternate translation: “liars who tell you that they are speaking my words to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who prophesy falsely to you in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: “I will allow Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to conquer them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to put them into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “name” refers to a person’s authority and reputation. Alternate translation: “based on your own authority and reputation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in your own name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name Jacob is a metonym for the man’s descendants. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “for the descendants of Jacob, but I will rescue them from it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: for Jacob, but he will be rescued from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for one of David’s descendants. Alternate translation: “a man descended from their King David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: David their king

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Jacob” and “Israel” are the two names of the ancestor of the Israelites, and these names are metonyms for the Israelites. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob … you Israelite people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my servant Jacob & Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob’s name is a metonym for his descendants. Yahweh speaks to Jacob as if he were speaking to another person. You may need to make explicit to where Jacob will return. Alternate translation: “Jacob will return to his own land … he will be secure” or “The descendants of Jacob will return … they will be secure” or “You descendants of Jacob will return … you will be secure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob will return & he will be secure

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place name “Zion” is a metonym for the people who live in Zion. Alternate translation: “No one cares about the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: No one cares for this Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places where people live are metonyms for the people who live in those places. Alternate translation: “I am about bring back the fortunes of the descendants of Jacob, and I will have compassion on them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to bring back the fortunes of Jacob’s tents and have compassion on his homes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for war. Alternate translation: “who have survived the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who have survived the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah speaks of himself as if he were the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh appeared to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rachel was the wife of Jacob/Israel and was the mother of the tribes of Joseph and Benjamin. Her name is a metonym for the women of Israel who are crying because the Babylonians have killed their children or taken them away. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: It is Rachel weeping for her children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim was the ancestor of the largest tribe in Israel. His name is a metonym for the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “I have certainly heard the descendants of Ephraim sorrowing” or “I have certainly heard the people of Israel sorrowing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have certainly heard Ephraim sorrowing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the man Judah is a metonym for the land on which his descendants, the people of the tribe of Judah, live, and the cities of Judah are spoken of as if they were the family of the man Judah, all of them living “there,” in the land of Judah. Alternate translation: “it will be as if the land were a house in which Judah lived with his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah and all its cities will live together there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the people of Israel and the people of Judah. The house in turn is spoken of as if it were a field in which Yahweh would sow seed, and the people and the animals they raise for food, milk, and skins are spoken of as if they are that seed. Alternate translation: “I will cause the people of Israel and Judah to become many people with many animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sow the houses of Israel and Judah with the descendants of man and beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Zedekiah do this. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Zedekiah king of Judah had imprisoned him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will certainly put him under the control of the king of Babylon” or “I will certainly allow the king of Babylon to do whatever he wants with him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he will certainly be given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “raised arm” is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the words “your great strength” and “your raised arm” form a doublet. Alternate translation: “by your great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: by your great strength and with your raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “guilt” is a metonym for Yahweh punishing people because they are guilty of doing evil things. Yahweh punishing people is spoken of as if he were pouring a large container full of liquid or small objects into people’s laps as they sit. Alternate translation: “you punish children for the sins of their parents” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: pour the guilt of men into the laps of their children after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Open eyes are a metonym for what the person sees. How a person lives is spoken of as if he were walking on a path. Alternate translation: “You see everything that people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for your eyes are open to all the ways of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” refers to God’s reputation. Alternate translation: “you have made yourself famous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you have made your name famous

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “strong hand” is a metonym for strength, and the phrase “raised arm” is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the phrases “strong hand” and “raised arm” form a doublet. Alternate translation: “by your great strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with a strong hand, with a raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The voice is a metonym for the message the speaker gives. Alternate translation: “But they did not obey what you said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But they did not obey your voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for war, where soldiers use swords. Alternate translation: “because soldiers will attack” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” means power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “you have given Jerusalem to the Chaldean army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the city has been given into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the city as if it were a small object that he could put into a person’s hand. The word “hand” is a metonym for the power that the hand puts into action. Alternate translation: “put this city under the power of the Chaldeans” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: give this city into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “eyes” represents what God sees. This could mean: (1) “doing what I consider evil” or (2) “doing evil knowing that I am watching” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: doing evil before my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” is a metonym for the people that live there. The words “wrath” and “fury” mean basically the same thing and emphasize how very angry he is. Alternate translation: “the people of Jerusalem have made me very angry since the day they built their city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: this city has been a provocation of my wrath and fury since the day that they built it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to Yahweh’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “I never thought at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: It never entered my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” means power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has given it to the king of Babylon” or “Yahweh has given the king of Babylon the power to rule it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: It is given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will want to work together to honor Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: one heart and one way to honor me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” is a metonym for power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has given it to the Chaldeans” or “Yahweh has given the Chaldeans power over it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: It has been given into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for people dying violently when soldiers kill with swords. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city is a metonym for the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: “the people who live in this city … do for the people who live there … give to the people who live there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: this city & do for it & give to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “song” is a metonym for the object about which people will sing the song. Alternate translation: “something about which all the people groups of the earth will sing songs of praise and honor to me, Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a song of praise and honor for all the nations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people who live in Judah. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: the nation of Israel (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: These towns’ names are metonyms for the people who live in the towns. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah … the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah & Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The throne is a metonym for the king. Alternate translation: “to be king over the house of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to sit on the throne of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The throne is a metonym for the king who sits on the throne. Alternate translation: “to rule the kingdom I have given to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to sit on his throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sight is a metonym for thinking. Alternate translation: “they no longer think of my people as a nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my people & are no longer a nation in their sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all the towns around Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of her cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” is a metonym for the control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: “under the control of the king of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” is a metonym for the control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: “You will not escape from his control” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not escape from his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for dying in war. Alternate translation: “You will not die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not die by the sword.

contextId.occurrenceNote: To incline the ear, to lean the head toward the speaker so as to hear better, is a metonym for paying attention to what the speaker is saying. Alternate translation: “did not … pay attention to what I said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: did not & incline their ears to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Eyes” here is a metonym for someone’s opinion or idea. Alternate translation: “what I consider to be right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: right in my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person’s name is a metonym for what people think of him. Alternate translation: “stopped doing what was right and did evil things that have made people think that I am evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: turned and polluted my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for soldiers who carry swords. Alternate translation: “enemy soldiers to kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” here is a metonym for the power or control that the enemies will exercise using their hands. AT; “I will allow their enemies to have complete control over them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give them into the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents control. Alternate translation: “to be conquered by their enemies” or “over to the control of their enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “voice” is a metonym for the command that Jonadab spoke. Alternate translation: “the command of Jonadab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the voice of Jonadab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “iniquity” and “sin” are metonyms for the persons who commit iniquity and sin. Alternate translation: “forgive them for their iniquity and their sin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: forgive their iniquity and their sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will allow the army of the king of Babylon to conquer Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: This city will be given into the hand of the army of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Weak hands are a metonym for a person who is afraid. Alternate translation: “he is causing the soldiers and all the people in the city to lose courage” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he is weakening the hands of the fighting men who remain in this city, and the hands of all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand has. Alternate translation: “you are able do whatever you want with him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he is in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to the men’s control or power. Alternate translation: “I will not … allow those men to capture you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not & give you into the hand of those men

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the people group is metonym for the people of that group. Alternate translation: “God of the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: God of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: “you will not escape from their power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will not escape from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: “will not escape from their power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will not escape from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. The reader should probably understand that many people will help the king do this. Alternate translation: “The army of the king of Babylon will capture you and will burn the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You will be captured by the hand of the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the men you fear will not harm you” or “I will not allow anyone to put you under the control of the people whom you fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you will not be given into the hand of the men whom you fear

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Eyes” here is a metonym for what the person thinks. Alternate translation: “it is what you consider to be right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: it is good in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Eyes” here is a metonym for what the person thinks. Alternate translation: “it is what you consider to be right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: it is good in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents the people. Alternate translation: “in charge of the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in charge of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having things in the hands here is probably a metaphor for carrying those things or having them in their possession. Alternate translation: “in their possession” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here King Asa represents his men. Alternate translation: “that King Asa ordered his men to dig” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that King Asa dug

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents the people. Alternate translation: “in charge of the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in charge of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: “what Yahweh our God says” or “we will obey Yahweh our God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to power and authority. Alternate translation: “rescue you from his power” or “rescue you from him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: rescue you from his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents a command. To not obey is like the people did not hear Yahweh’s command. Alternate translation: “if you do not obey my commands, even though I am Yahweh, your God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: if you do not listen to my voice, the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being hungry for food is used to describe famine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: we will not go hungry for food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sword” represents war. The Israelites experiencing war even if they go to Egypt is spoken of as if the sword would chase after the people catch up with them. Alternate translation: “you will experience the terrible results of war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword that you fear will overtake you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents what Yahweh commanded. Alternate translation: “to what Yahweh your God commanded” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “you will die in warfare” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will die by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “to give us over to the Chaldeans” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents commands. And here “to listen” means “to obey.” Alternate translation: “would not obey Yahweh’s command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: refused to listen to Yahweh’s voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the king’s “throne” and “pavilion” are used to refer to his royal authority. Alternate translation: “I will cause him to rule as king over the people of Egypt. He will place his throne and pavilion over these stones you have buried” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will place his throne over these stones that you, Jeremiah, have buried & ebuchadnezzar will place his pavilion over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” refers to Nebuchadnezzar who represents his whole army. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar’s army will come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Everyone will die in battle whom I have decided will die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Anyone who is assigned to the sword will be given to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “I” refers to Yahweh. This represents Yahweh sending the Babylonian army to light a fire. Alternate translation: “Then I will cause the Babylonian army to light a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Then I will light a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar’s army will … They will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar will & He will

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represent the people. Alternate translation: “all the people of all the nations of the earth will curse you and hate you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be a curse and a reproach among all the nations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people. Alternate translation: “I punished the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I punished Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “by causing enemies to kill some of them, others to starve to death, and others to die because of disease” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with the sword, with famine, and with the plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “in Yahweh’s name” means “in Yahweh’s authority” or “as Yahweh’s representative.” Alternate translation: “We will not obey this message that you say Yahweh told you to tell us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: About the word that you have told us in Yahweh’s name—we will not listen to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “enemy soldiers were killing some of us and some of us were dying of hunger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: were dying by sword and famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” refers to Yahweh’s commands. Alternate translation: “you would not obey his commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you would not listen to his voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” represents the people. Alternate translation: “all the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” represents the people. Alternate translation: “all the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents the whole being of Yahweh. And, “mouth” represents the whole person. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “No person of Judah living in the land of Egypt will ever call upon me again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: My name will no longer be called upon by the mouths of any of the men of Judah in all the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “Then those whom the enemies do not kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Then the survivors of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “I will allow the enemies who want to kill Pharaoh Hophra, the king of Egypt, to defeat him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to give Pharaoh Hophra king of Egypt into the hand of his enemies and into the hand of those who seek to kill him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. And, Nebuchadnezzar represents his whole army. The phrase “sought his life” is an idiom that means to want to kill someone. Alternate translation: “when I allowed the army of Nebuchadnezzar to defeat Zedekiah king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: when I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, his enemy who sought his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: “that the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” represents all the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “The Egyptians rise … The Egyptians say … We will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt rises & Egypt says & I will

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “horses” and “chariots” represent the soldiers who use horses and chariots in battle. The leaders of Egypt are ordering their soldiers to start the battle. Alternate translation: “Go up to battle, you soldiers on horses. Fight furiously, you soldiers in chariots” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up, horses & e angry, you chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “earth” is a metonym for the people of the earth and a generalization for the people who know what has happened to Egypt. All the people of the earth hearing the Egyptians crying is spoken of as if their laments filled the earth. Alternate translation: “All the people of the earth hear you crying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth is filled with your laments

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: “when the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the people of Egypt” or “the Egyptians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” here represents soldiers carrying weapons. The enemy soliders killing people is spoken of as if their swords were devouring people. Alternate translation: “your enemies will kill people all around you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword will devour those around you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the enemy soldiers who are carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “Let us run away from our enemies because they are killing us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Let us leave this sword that is beating us down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, will allow the people from the north to defeat the Egyptians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: She will be given into the hand of people from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” represents the people. Alternate translation: “all the people of Egypt and the gods they worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt and her gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. The phrase “seeking their lives” is an idiom that mean to want to kill someone. Alternate translation: “I will allow those who are wanting to kill them to defeat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am giving them into the hand of the ones seeking their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. “Nebuchadnezzar … his servants” names specifically “the ones seeking their lives.” Alternate translation: “that is, I will allow Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his servants to defeat the Egyptians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: and into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Pharaoh” represents the Egyptians army. Alternate translation: “before Pharaoh’s army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: before Pharaoh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Moab” represents the people. Alternate translation: “To the people of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: To Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Nebo” represents the people. Alternate translation: “How terrible it is for the people of Nebo, for their city is devastated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to Nebo, for it has been devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Kiriathaim has been humiliated” represents the people being humiliated. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemy has captured the city of Kiriathaim and humiliated the people who live there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]]and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Kiriathaim has been humiliated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fortress has been disgraced” represents the people being disgraced. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemy has destroyed the fortress in Kiriathaim and disgraced its people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]]and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Her fortress has been disgraced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the enemy army carrying weapons. Alternate translation: “your enemies will chase after you and kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a sword will go after you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the children who lived in Moab or (2) “children” is a metonym that represents the people of Moab in general. Alternate translation: “The people of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Her children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “no people from any city will escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: no city will escape

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “valley” and “plain” represent the cities and the people in those places Alternate translation: “So the enemy army will destroy everything in the valleys and on the plains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: So the valley will perish and the plain will be devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents a person’s life. And “shedding blood” is an idiom that means to kill. Alternate translation: “from killing people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from shedding blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Moab” represents the people. Alternate translation: “Then the people of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Then Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “staff” and “rod” represent the power and political support that Moab provided to other nations. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Moab’s enemies have ended her great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the strong staff, the honored rod, has been broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Moab” represents the people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people are disgraced, for the enemy army has destroyed Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab has been shamed, for it has been shattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Israel” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel … Were they found … at them … about them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel & Was he found & at him & about him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “his conceit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the conceit in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his” refers to Moab which represents the people of Moab. Alternate translation: “their defiant speech … like their deeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his defiant speech & like his deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Moab represents the people. To turn one’s back is a sign of feeling ashamed. Alternate translation: “The people of Moab turn their backs in shame” or “The people of Moab are ashamed and will not show their faces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab turns its back in shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hearts” represent a person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “Moab’s soldiers will be afraid like a woman about to give birth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hearts of Moab’s soldiers will be like the hearts of women in birth labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “in the shadow” represents protection or shelter. Alternate translation: “will hide in Heshbon for protection” or “will go to Heshbon for shelter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will stand in the shadow of Heshbon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Molech” represents the people who worship Molech. Alternate translation: “Why do the people who worship Molech” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Why does Molech

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Israel” represents the people of Israel. “Those” refers to people of Ammon, who represent the land that they took from Israel. Alternate translation: “Then the people of Israel will again possess the land that the people of Ammon took away from them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For Israel will possess those who possessed him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Esau” represents the people of Edom. The Edomites were descendants of Esau. Alternate translation: “I will cause the people of Edom to experience disaster when I punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I am bringing the disaster of Esau on him at the time that I punish him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Esau” represents the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “the people of Edom … their hiding … they will not … hide themselves … Their children … they are gone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Esau & his hiding & he will not & hide himself & His children & he is gone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the cup” is a metonym that represents the contents in the cup that the people must drink. The people experiencing Yahweh’s punishment is spoken of as if Yahweh’s punishment were liquid in a cup and the people must drink it. Alternate translation: “must certainly experience my punishment … for you will certainly experience my punishment” or “I will certainly still punish … for I will certainly punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: must certainly drink some of the cup & for you will certainly drink

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the whole person. People deceiving themselves is spoken of as if their pride deceived them. Alternate translation: “you have become prideful, but you have deceived yourselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your heart’s pride has deceived you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” represents the people. “It” refers to the land. Alternate translation: “the people of Edom will run from their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Edom run from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Hamath” and “Arpad” represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people who live in Hamath and Arpad will be ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamath and Arpad will be ashamed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Damascus” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people of Damascus have become very weak. They turn … seizes them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Damascus has become very weak & t turns & seizes it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing the enemy army to light a fire is spoken of as if Yahweh will light the fire. Alternate translation: “I will cause the enemy army to light a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will light a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Nebuchadnezzar” represents his army. Alternate translation: “the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon was going to attack” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon was going to attack

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nation” represents the people living there. Alternate translation: “Attack this nation, whose people feel safe and secure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Attack the nation at ease, that lives in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are a metonym for Yahweh causing enemies to destroy Elam. Alternate translation: “I will cause Elam’s enemies to destroy Elam” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will shatter Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: the people of Elam (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the enemy army carrying their weapons. Alternate translation: “the enemy army to pursue and kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” represents Yahweh’s right to rule and judge as the king. Alternate translation: “I will judge the people of Elam” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put my throne in Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah speaks of the people who live in the city of Babylon as if they were the city itself, and he speaks of the city as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “The people of Babylon have surrendered … they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: She has surrendered & she has done

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” refers to the armies that will attack Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the oppressor’s sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers collectively to all the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the army of the king of Assyria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” is a metonym for the people who live in the land of Babylon. Alternate translation: “the Babylonian people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers collectively to all the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel to their homeland … they will be satisfied” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel to his homeland & he will be satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to having a sword come down on people to kill them. Alternate translation: “Kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Put them to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” represents war. Yahweh speaks of Babylon’s enemies killing them in battle as if he were placing those people under the sword’s power. Alternate translation: “Kill them in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Put them to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: These sounds are heard during battle and great destruction. They are spoken of in the present tense to indicate that this will certainly happen soon. Alternate translation: “The sounds of fierce battle and terrible destruction are going to happen soon in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The sounds of battle and enormous destruction are in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s anger that causes him to send enemies against Babylon is spoken of as if Yahweh had an armory and weapons. To open an armory is a metonym for preparing for battle. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has prepared for war and is sending the nations to attack Babylon in his anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has opened his armory and is bringing out the weapons for carrying out his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the land” is a metonym for the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “in order that the people who live in Israel might live in peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in order to bring rest to the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “War will soon happen to … and to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: A sword is against & and against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “War will soon happen to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: A sword against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “War will soon happen to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: A sword is coming against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the Babylonian people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “Israel” and “Judah” are metonyms for the people of Israel and Judah. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh of hosts, the God of the people of Israel and Judah, has not forsaken them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel and Judah are not forsaken by their God, by Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the city is a metonym for the people who live there, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “the people of Babylon … they are not healed … leave them … their guilt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon & she is not healed & leave her & her guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents the people of Israel. God being their “portion” is an idiom that means that they worship him. Alternate translation: “the portion of Israel” or “whom the people of Israel worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the portion of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is a metonym for the people of Babylon, and it is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “attack the people of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: attack her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is a metonym for the people who live on the land. Shaking and being in anguish are metonyms for being very afraid. Alternate translation: “the people who live in Babylon will shake with fear and be in anguish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land will shake and be in anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is a metonym for the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: “against the people of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Daughter of Babylon” here is another name for the people who live in Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The daughter of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “praise” is a metonym for the thing that people praised, and the word “earth” is a metonym for the people living on the earth. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “enemies have seized Babylon, the nation that everyone on earth praised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the praise of all the earth is seized

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bel was the main god of the Babylonians and represents the whole country and the people that worshiped it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will punish Bel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ruler is a metonym for the nations under his control. Alternate translation: “Nations will fight against other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ruler will be against ruler

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “the people of Babylon … their land … their slaughtered ones … their midst” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon & her land & her slaughtered ones & her midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “over the Babylonians … come for them … the Babylonians have made … their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: over Babylon & come for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “the people of Babylon … their land … their slaughtered ones … their midst … over the Babylonians … come for them … the Babylonians have made … their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon has made & her land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a metonym for war, in which soldiers use swords. Alternate translation: “You who have survived the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Survivors of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “their carved idols … their land … the Babylonians … their highest fortresses … to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her carved idols & her land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “their highest fortresses … to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her highest fortresses & to her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “destroying the people of Babylon … their loud voices” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: destroying Babylon & her loud voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “against the people of Babylon—yes, against Babylon!—and their warriors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: against her—against Babylon!—and her warriors

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “their princes, their sages, their officials, and their soldiers … their high gates … their aid … for them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her princes, her sages, her officials, and her soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “their high gates … their aid … for them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her high gates & her aid & for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reader should understand that removing his prison clothes represents making him a free man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: removed Jehoiachin’s prison clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob and Israel were two names for one man, and these two phrases refer to the same group of people. Alternate translation: “all you descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Jacob, all you clans of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “you sinned and made the land I gave you disgusting to me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: you defiled my land, you made my inheritance an abomination!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that the people are fully aware of their shameful behavior. Alternate translation: “Let us be completely humiliated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Let us lie down in shame & ay our shame cover us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the command. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Circumcise yourselves & remove the foreskins of your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the command. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Report in Judah and let it be heard in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. Alternate translation: “The cities will be empty. There will be no one left to live in them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The cities will be abandoned, for there will be no one to inhabit them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences say the same thing, the second is more specific than the first. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: no harm will come upon us, and we will not see sword or famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the Israelites do not know the language of those people. It may imply that the Israelites have not had much contact with them. Alternate translation: “It is a nation whose language you will not understand at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: It is a nation whose language you do not know, nor will you understand what they say

contextId.occurrenceNote: These four clauses each mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: do not pray for this people, and do not lift up a lamenting wail or say a prayer on their behalf, and do not petition me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences say the same thing, The second emphasizes the message of the first. Alternate translation: “Tell them my message, but they will not listen to you or answer you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: So proclaim all these words to them, but they will not listen to you & roclaim these things to them, but they will not answer you.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” here refers to the people of Judah. These three phrases mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: that they have followed and served, that they have walked after and sought, and that they have worshiped

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions are similar in meaning. They imply that the people of Judah are wondering why Yahweh is not saving them. Alternate translation: “Why does Yahweh not save us if he is the king in Zion?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is Yahweh not in Zion? Is her king no longer there?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These statements express the same idea in more than one way for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I am hurt because of the hurt of the daughter of my people &  mourn at the horrible things that have happened to her; I am dismayed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is Jeremiah speaking. These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how much Jeremiah is weeping. Alternate translation: “I wish I could make more tears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: If only my head could produce water, and my eyes be a fountain of tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is mourning for the land of Israel as if it were a person who died. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sing a song of mourning & a funeral song will be sung for the meadows

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. They emphasize that they are to call funeral singers to come. Alternate translation: “Get women who are trained in mourning and bring those women here” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Summon funeral singers; let them come & Send out for women skilled at lamenting; let them come

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the command to listen to what Yahweh says. In the second phrase Yahweh’s “mouth” is a metonym for himself. Alternate translation: “listen to what Yahweh says. Pay attention to his words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: hear Yahweh’s word; pay attention to the messages that come from his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the large number dead bodies. Alternate translation: “dead bodies will fall all over the place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the corpses of men will fall like dung & like grain stalks after the reapers

contextId.occurrenceNote: “understands who I am and knows me.” Both of these phrases have similar meanings. They emphasize people knowing who Yahweh is and understanding who he is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: has insight and knows me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. This means that no one has control over the various things that will happen to him during his life. Alternate translation: “that no person controls what will happen to him; no one is able to direct the events that he will experience” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: that the way of a man does not come from himself & o person walking directs his own steps

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases have the same meaning. Jeremiah repeats this idea three times to emphasize the utter destruction of Israel. This speaks of the enemy armies attacking the people of Israel as if the armies were a fierce animal attacking and devouring its prey. Alternate translation: “For they have fiercely attacked the people of Israel and consumed them so as to completely destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For they have devoured Jacob and consumed him so as to completely destroy him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three sentences have similar meanings. The first and second one strengthens the thought in the third. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I have abandoned my house; I have forsaken my inheritance &  have given my beloved into the hands of her enemies.

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase have the same meaning and emphasize that the doe leaves her young deer because she cannot provide for them. A doe is a female deer. Alternate translation: “the deer leaves her young in the field” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the doe leaves her young in the fields and abandons them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people are asking if Yahweh is unconcerned with his people and unable to help them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “you should not be like a stranger in the land, like a foreign wanderer who stretches out and spends just one night.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: why will you be like a stranger in the land, like a foreign wanderer who stretches out and spends just one night?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh repeats this idea of sending away his people to add emphasis to it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Send them out from before me, for them to go away

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people have, indeed, forsaken Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: You have forsaken me & you have gone back from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize the safety that God provides. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: rescue you from & and redeem you from

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have a similar meaning. God said basically the same thing twice for emphasis. It was customary to take food or wine to people whose relative had died. Yahweh has removed all comfort from the people because of their sin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: No one must share any food in mourning to comfort them because of the deaths & none must give a comforting cup to his father or his mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “bowed down to” mean basically the same thing as “worshiped” and describe the posture that people used in worship. God said essentially the same thing twice for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: worshiped and bowed down to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “They” and “them” refer to the false gods that the ancestors taught them to believe in. The two phrases mean basically the same thing, with the second explaining how they “are empty.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: They are empty; there is no profit in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means basically the same thing as the previous one and adds emphasis to Jeremiah’s prayer. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Make them very afraid, but do not make me afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: May they be dismayed, but do not let me be dismayed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. Jeremiah speaks of his enemies planning to kill him as if they had dug a pit for him to fall into and set traps in which to capture him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For they have dug a pit to capture me and have hidden traps for my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah speaks of Yahweh forgiving his enemies’ sins as if someone had written their sins down and Yahweh would erase them. This phrase means the same thing as the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “Do not pardon their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not wipe their sins away from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases both speak of the people being stubborn. In the first phrase, Yahweh speaks of the people being stubborn as if they had made their necks stiff. Alternate translation: “stubbornly refused to listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: stiffened their neck and refused to listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh repeats the same basic idea four times for emphasis. Babylon will take away all the wealth of Israel, including the king’s possessions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: all the wealth & all of its riches, all of its precious items and all the treasures

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the way others mock him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I have become a laughingstock all day long; everyone mocks me

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these phrases refer to Nebuchadnezzar and his army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon & their enemies & those seeking their life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the word “Woe” several times for emphasis. He addresses the various people who would normally show great sadness when someone dies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe, my brother! & Woe, my sister! & Woe, master! & Woe, majesty!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two metaphors have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. Alternate translation: “I will help them to prosper in Chaldea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will build them up, and not tear them down &  will plant them, and not uproot them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that it is Yahweh who has rescued the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “For Yahweh has rescued the people of Israel from their enemy who was too strong for them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For Yahweh has ransomed Jacob and has redeemed him from the hand that was too strong for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speaker repeats the phrase to show either that Yahweh punished him severely or that Ephraim learned what Yahweh wanted to teach him through punishing him. The words “I have been punished” can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “You punished me. Yes, you punished me severely” or “You punished me, and I learned from you when you punished me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You punished me, and I have been punished

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize that Yahweh’s law will become a part of them, rather than merely written on stone. Here “heart” represents “emotions” or “mind.” Alternate translation: “My law will be part of their thoughts and emotions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will place my law within them and will write it on their heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that Judah has become desolate. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: It is desolate, a place with neither man nor beast,” in the cities of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem that are desolate having neither man nor beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases describe being at war by the ability to see or hear it. Alternate translation: “where we will not experience the hardships of war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: where we will not see any war, where we will not hear the sound of the trumpet

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these statements mean basically the same thing and emphasize how badly the nations will treat the people of Judah after Yahweh punishes them. Alternate translation: “People will be terrified when they see what has happened to you. They will curse and mock you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: You will become an object of cursing and a horror, an object for speaking curses, and something dishonorable

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. They emphasize that Yahweh knows that the people were worshiping false gods. Alternate translation: “Yes, Yahweh knows what you were doing, and he does not forget” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: For Yahweh calls this to mind; it comes to his thoughts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. Being and dying in battle is spoken of as if the soldiers stumble and fall. Alternate translation: “The Egyptian soldiers suffer defeat and die in the north by the Euphrates River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They stumble in the north and fall beside the Euphrates River

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s sword as if it were devouring people and drinking blood.
