contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the great number of people who will die, by comparing their bodies to cut stalks of grain. Alternate translation: “like stalks of grain fall everywhere after the farmers cut them down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like grain stalks after the reapers

contextId.occurrenceNote: A scarecrow is a man-like figure made to scare birds and prevent them from eating the crops. Here Yahweh compares the idols to scarecrows because they are not capable of doing anything. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: What they make with their hands is like scarecrows

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the sound of the raging fire to the sound of a severe storm. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: that will sound like the roar of a storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will scatter them like chaff that is blown away by the wind.” Yahweh is saying He will scatter His people throughout the world just as chaff is scattered by the wind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will scatter them like chaff that perishes in the desert wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the donkeys panting because they are thirsty by saying that they pant like jackals. Jackals are fiece wild dog which pant a lot. Alternate translation: “they pant in the wind like thirsty jackals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they pant in the wind like jackals

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question speaks of the possibility of Yahweh being unconcerned with helping his people as if he were a stranger just travelling though a place unconcerned with those living there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: why will you be like a stranger in the land, like a foreign wanderer & just one night

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the possibility of Yahweh being unable to help his people as if he were a confused warrior who was unable to rescue anyone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You do nothing to help us, like someone who is astounded or like a warrior who has no power to rescue us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Why are you like someone who is astounded, or like a warrior who has no power to rescue?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is compared to the mouth of Yahweh because he will be used to speak Yahweh’s message. Alternate translation: “you will speak for me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be like my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares Jeremiah to a wall because the people will not be able to defeat him. Alternate translation: “I will make you strong, like a bronze wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like an impenetrable bronze wall to this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person who trusts in man instead of Yahweh will be like a plant that struggles to survive in an infertile land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a small bush

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person who trusts in Yahweh will always prosper, just like a tree does when it is planted by a river. It is not affected when there is no rain. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he will be like a tree that someone has planted by water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he will be like a tree planted by water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his being able to remake Israel as he see fit to the way that the potter is able to remake a lump of clay as he sees fit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like clay in a potter’s hand—that is how you are in my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah compares Yahweh helping him and defending him against his enemies to a powerful warrior. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh is with me like a powerful warrior

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “You are as beautiful as Gilead or the summit of Lebanon” or (2) “You give me as much pleasure as Gilead or the summit of Lebanon.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: You are like Gilead, or like the summit of Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pain that the king will feel when his enemies defeat him will be as intense as the pain a woman feels in childbirth. Alternate translation: “when you experience pain as intense as the pain of a woman in childbirth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: when the labor pains come upon you, pain like that of a woman in labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who are drunk are not able to control themselves. Likewise, Jeremiah has lost control of himself out of fear of Yahweh’s punishment. Alternate translation: “I am like a drunk man; I cannot control myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I have become like a drunk man, like a man whom wine has overpowered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The danger of their actions is spoken of as if they were about to fall off the slippery edge of a cliff in the dark and injure themselves. Alternate translation: “there actions are unstable and dangerous, like walking on a slippery place in the darkness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their way will be like a slippery place in the darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sodom and Gomorrah were cities that were so wicked that God destroyed them with fire from heaven. Alternate translation: “They all became as evil as Sodom … as wicked as Gomorrah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: All of them have become like Sodom & like Gomorrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The good figs represent those Judean exiles sent to the land of Chaldea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: just like these good figs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh had destroyed a place of worship at Shiloh, and he was threatening to destroy this place of worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: then I will make this house like Shiloh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rotten figs are useless because they cannot be eaten, and Yahweh sees no use for the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will make them like rotten figs that are too bad to be eaten

contextId.occurrenceNote: A woman about to give birth is in great pain and unable to do anything. The young men are so frightened that their bodies hurt, and they are unable to fight. Alternate translation: “The young men are holding their bellies like a woman giving birth; they all look sick because they are so afraid.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do I see every young man with his hand on his loins like a woman bearing a child? Why have all their faces become pale?

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shepherd cares for and protects his sheep, and Yahweh is promising to care for and protect the Israelites. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a shepherd keeps his sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means they will be strong and healthy, and they will prosper. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a watered garden

contextId.occurrenceNote: When people train calves, they strike them and otherwise cause them to suffer. Yahweh had caused the people of Israel to suffer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been punished like an untrained calf

contextId.occurrenceNote: No one can count the stars in the sky or the sand on the seashore, and no one will be able to count the descendants of David and Levi who serve Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As the hosts of heaven cannot be counted, and as the sand of the seashores cannot be measured, so I will increase the descendants of David my servant and the Levites who serve before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking or destroying everything in Egypt is compared to how a shepherd carefully cleans off his clothes. Alternate translation: “He will take or destroy everything valuable in Egypt just as a shepherd is careful to get every insect off of his clothes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He will clean out the land of Egypt just as shepherds clean vermin off their clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Nile river floods its banks once a year, covering the surrounding area with water. Yahweh compares the kingdom of Egypt to the Nile because the Egyptian people think they are mighty enough to destroy cities in all the lands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt rises like the Nile

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the nation of Babylon who will be as overwhelming to the nation of Egypt as the these two mountains are to the plains that surround them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: someone will come like Mount Tabor and Mount Carmel by the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares soldiers to “fattened bulls” because the soldiers are well cared for by the Egyptians just as a farmer takes care of a bull and makes it fat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: soldiers in her midst are like a fattened bull

contextId.occurrenceNote: The inability of the Egyptians to do anything to stop their enemy is spoken of as if they were snakes that can only hiss and crawl away. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt hisses like a snake and crawls away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemies coming with the weapons to destroy the Egyptians is spoken of as if they were woodcutters with axes preparing to cut down a tree. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They are going toward her like woodcutters with axes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people fleeing from their cities into the desert is compared to a bush or shrub that grows in the desert. Alternate translation: “become like a shrub that grows in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: become like a juniper bush in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes the people should leave their cities and live in the rocky cliffs to hide from their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Become like a dove & in the rocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases compare how a powerful army will descend on Moab and conquer it to the way an eagle swoops down to capture its prey. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the enemy will come flying like an eagle, spreading out his wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares the fear that will overwhelm the soldiers of Moab to the fear a woman may feel when she is about to give birth to her child. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: in that day the hearts of Moab’s soldiers & women in birth labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when Yahweh punishes the people of Edom, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion attacks sheep. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “When I punish the people of Edom, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion comes out of forest and attacks sheep in the pasture” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: he will go up like a lion from the forests of the Jordan to the green pasturelands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when the enemy army attacks it will be vicious and unexpected. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: someone will attack like an eagle, and swoop down and spread his wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The water of the sea is always moving and is never still. This is compared to the people who cannot rest because they are so anxious about the bad news they heard. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They become as troubled as the sea, which cannot stay calm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Male goats tend to be more independent than the rest of the flock. This could mean: (1) they should be the first to leave Babylon or (2) they should lead the rest of the Israelites away from Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: be like male goats that leave

contextId.occurrenceNote: The effectiveness of the arrows of the attacking nations are spoken of as if they were soldiers that always accomplish their mission. The idiom “empty-handed” means “without success.” Alternate translation: Each of their arrows are like skilled soldiers that always hit their target” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Their arrows are like a skilled warrior who does not return empty-handed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The joy of the people of Babylon is compared to a calf who runs around joyfully in a pasture. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you jump around like a calf stamping in its pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are compared to stallions that are making loud noises because they are excited. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you neigh like a powerful horse

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) reduce the city to piles of rubble that look like stacks of grain or (2) stack up the plunder from the city like piles of grain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: pile her up like heaps of grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The weakness of the Babylonian soldiers is spoken of as if they were women. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “they will all become as weak as women” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they will become like women

contextId.occurrenceNote: The loud noise that the soldiers make is compared to the loud noise of the sea. Alternate translation: “The sound that they make is very loud, like the sound of the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Their sound is like the sea roar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The anguish that they feel because the enemy coming to attack them is compared to the anguish that a woman feels when she is about to give birth to a baby. Alternate translation: “like a woman who is about to give birth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a woman giving birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when Yahweh punishes the people of Babylon, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion attacks sheep. This can be stated in the first person. Alternate translation: “When I punish the people of Babylon, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion comes out of mountains and attacks sheep in the pasture” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: He goes up like a lion from the heights of the Jordan to the enduring grazing place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The large number of enemy soldiers is spoken of as if they were a mass of locusts invading the city. Alternate translation: “with a large number of soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a swarm of locusts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares a great number of horses to a swarm of locusts. Alternate translation: “bring many horses with soldiers quickly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: bring up horses like swarming locusts

contextId.occurrenceNote: People thresh grain by trampling it on a threshing floor, and Yahweh speaks of people punishing the daughter of Babylon as if they were threshing grain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: is like a threshing floor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Babylon is compared to a monster. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like a monster

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lambs and goats do not know before it happens that people are going to slaughter them, and the Babylonians will not know before it happens that Yahweh is going to destroy them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like lambs & male goats

contextId.occurrenceNote: The waves of the ocean and of flooding rivers make a loud sound, and the enemies will make a very loud sound as they come. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: enemies roar like the waves of many waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: The stone and scroll will disappear in the water, the water will destroy the scroll, and Babylon will no longer look like a city or have buildings for people to live in. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon will sink like this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “someone” represents a king and his army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: someone who will destroy nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “a voice” represents a messenger. Alternate translation: “a messenger comes and tells about what is happening in Dan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a voice is bringing news from Dan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a synecdoche for all of the different weapons that people use in war. Alternate translation: “They will use their weapons to conquer your strong cities that you trusted to protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: They will beat down with a sword your fortified cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nation” represents the army of the nation. Alternate translation: “the army of a great nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a great nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Jerusalem” here is a synecdoche for all the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents Jeremiah, emphasizing his feelings and emotions. Alternate translation: “I feel sick deep down inside me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart is sick

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their “tongues” to emphasize their speech. Alternate translation: “They teach deceitful things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Their tongues teach deceitful things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s speech is represented by his “mouth.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the mouth of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Jeremiah is speaking as if he were the whole tribe of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jeremiah represents the whole tribe of Israel. Alternate translation: “but we must bear it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: but I must bear it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jeremiah represents the whole tribe of Israel. Alternate translation: “Our enemies have taken our children away from us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: They have taken my children away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the men refer to their “hand” to emphasize that they plan to kill him themselves. Alternate translation: “we ourselves will kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you will die by our hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is referred to by his “feet” to emphasize that he is walking. Alternate translation: “before he causes you to trip and fall as you walk” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: before he causes your feet to stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “gates,” which keep enemies out of cities and where people conduct business and government, is a synecdoche for Judah’s cities, and Judah’s cities are a metonym for the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “let her cities fall apart” or “let the people in her cities become unable to defend themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: let her gates fall apart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are referred to by their “feet” to emphasize their walking away from Yahweh. Alternate translation: “have not kept themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: have not held back their feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eye” represents Yahweh who sees all that they do. Alternate translation: “I am watching everything they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eye is on all their ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents Yahweh who sees. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They cannot conceal their iniquity from me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Their iniquity cannot be concealed from before my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sinful habits of the people are spoken of as if their sins had been engraved on their own hearts. The word “hearts” refers to the whole person: their thoughts, emotions, and actions. Alternate translation: “engraved in their very beings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: engraved on the tablet of their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “lips” represents Jeremiah who spoke. The word “proclamations” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “the proclamations that I spoke” or “the things that I proclaimed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the proclamations that came from my lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “feet” represents Jeremiah. Alternate translation: “have hidden traps for me” or “have hidden traps for me to step on” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: have hidden traps for my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents Pashhur. Alternate translation: “you will see it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your eyes will see it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “heart” and “bones” represent Jeremiah’s innermost being. Jeremiah speaks of being unable to not speak Yahweh’s message as if Yahweh’s message were a fire that burns within him. Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s word is like a fire that burns deep within me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it is like a fire in my heart, held within my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “days” represents all the days of Jeremiah’s life. Alternate translation: “my life is filled with shame” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my days are filled with shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” refers to the people from those nations that pass by. Alternate translation: “Then many people from various nations will pass by this city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Then many nations will pass by this city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “They strengthen those who do evil” or “They encourage people who do evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: They strengthen the hands of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The voice is a synecdoche for the person, and the same word can be translated “listen” or “obey.” Alternate translation: “obey Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: listen to the voice of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The face is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “cause Yahweh to be less angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: appease the face of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “Have those kings’ ambassadors, who … Judah, take them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Send them by the hand of those kings’ ambassadors who & Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah gave the scroll to Elasah so that Elasah could take it to Babylon. The reader should understand that Elasah probably put the scroll in a container to keep it safe as he traveled. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: by the hand of Elasah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth” and “eyes” represent the whole person. Alternate translation: “Zedekiah himself will see and directly speak with Nebuchadnezzar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: His mouth will speak to the king’s mouth, and his eyes will see the king’s eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is represented by his “face.” This phrase shows Yahweh’s displeasure with the city. Alternate translation: “I have turned away from you” or “I am no longer concerned with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I hide my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “he had Jeremiah the prophet proclaim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: he proclaimed by the hand of Jeremiah the prophet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. The reader should also understand that others probably helped the king of Babylon kill Zedekiah’s sons. Alternate translation: “forced Zedekiah to watch as the king’s soldiers killed Zedekiah’s sons” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons before his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ishmael” represents himself and the ten men with him. Alternate translation: “Then Ishmael and the ten men with him killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Then Ishmael killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here King Baasha represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “against Baasha, king of Israel, and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: against King Baasha of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ishmael represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: “Ishmael and his men filled it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ishmael son of Nethaniah filled it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ishmael represents himself and his men. Alternate translation: “Ishmael and his men captured” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ishmael captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ishmael” represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: “Ishmael and his men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ishmael son of Nethaniah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ishmael” represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: “Ishmael and his men … found them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ishmael son of Nethaniah & found him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ishmael” represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: “whom Ishmael and his men had captured” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: whom Ishmael had captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: “He” refers to Ishmael who represents himself and the eight men with him. Alternate translation: “They went to the people of Ammon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He went to the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men are used to refer to all the people because they are the leaders in their families. Alternate translation: “anyone who sets out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
contextId.quoteString: all the men who set out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is referred to by the part of the city where people walk. This means the people did evil things in public places. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem” or “the public places of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the streets of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “streets” represent the public places in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “in the public places of Jerusalem” or “in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the streets of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouths” and “hands” represent the whole person. Alternate translation: “have done what you promised to do when you said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: have said with your mouths and carried out with your hands what you said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the whole person. The person’s sad crying is compared to the sad music played on a flute at a funeral. Alternate translation: “I cry sadly for Moab. My cries are like the sad music a person plays on a flute at a funeral” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart is lamenting for Moab like a flute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the pit” and “the trap” represent all the different bad things that will happen to the people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: fall into the pit & caught in the trap

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “forehead” and “top of the heads” represent the people of Moab as a whole. Alternate translation: “It will burn up all the people in Moab who noisily boasted very much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: It will devour the forehead of Moab and the top of the heads of the boastful people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the time when the Medes and Persians conquered Babylon in 539 BC. Here “nation” represents their armies. Alternate translation: “the armies of a great nation and many kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a great nation and many kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. The reader should also understand that others probably helped the king of Babylon kill Zedekiah’s sons. Alternate translation: “forced Zedekiah to watch as the king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons before his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: this is Yahweh’s declaration

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God speaks as though he were not speaking directly to his people. Alternate translation: “But you, my people, have exchanged me, your glorious God, for what cannot help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: But my people have exchanged their glory for what cannot help them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Though Yahweh was speaking to the people of Israel, he used the third person as though he were talking to someone else about Israel. Alternate translation: “Israel, are you a slave? Were you born at home? So why have you become plunder?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Is Israel a slave? Was he born in his master’s home? So why has he become plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” refers to Yahweh. Since Yahweh is speaking, “him” can also be translated as “me.” Alternate translation: “they will boast in me” or “they will praise me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: in him they will glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking of himself in third person. Alternate translation: “my word … be me, Yahweh of hosts, not” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh & beg Yahweh of hosts not

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear why Yahweh speaks of himself by name. Alternate translation: “you urged people to rebel against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: you proclaimed rebellion against Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear why Yahweh speaks of himself by name. Alternate translation: “he has urged people to rebel against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: he has proclaimed rebellion against Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues speaking about the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “you will worship Yahweh your God … your king … over you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: they will worship Yahweh their God & their king & over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear why Jeremiah is referring to himself by name here. You may translate using first person, as the UST does. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeremiah the prophet was imprisoned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “him” refers to Jeremiah. It is not clear why Jeremiah is referring to himself by name here. You may translate using first person, as the UST does. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: had imprisoned him

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear why Jeremiah is referring to himself by name here. You may translate using first person, as the UST does. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeremiah said

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. contextId.quoteString: she is not healed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Every metalworker’s idols put him to shame” or “As for every metalworker, his idols shame him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Every metalworker is put to shame by his idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the enemies have overcome the whole city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: his city has been taken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the enemies have taken control of all the fords over the river” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the fords over the river are seized

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “how” here shows that something that people thought was impossible has happened. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “We never thought that enemies could capture Babylon, but they have captured her … We never thought that Babylon could become a ruined place, but it has become a ruined place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: How Babylon has been captured & How Babylon has become a ruined place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Its roaring waves have covered her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: She is covered with its roaring waves

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when you hear the news that is in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the news that is heard in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase can be changed to have an active verb. Alternate translation: “her enemies have captured her warriors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: her warriors have been captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “The invaders willl completely demolish the thick walls of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The thick walls of Babylon will be completely demolished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “they will burn her high gates” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: her high gates will be burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “they will burn up everything that the nations try to do for her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: everything & will be burned up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “So they besieged the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: So the city was besieged

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the Babylonians broke through the wall around the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the city was broken into

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. This could mean: (1) “the Chaldeans scattered his entire army” or (2) “all of his soldiers ran away in different directions.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: All his army was scattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh says what the people of Judah will say when the destruction comes. The words “us” and “our” refer to the people of Judah and does not include Yahweh. This may be written instead as a command from Yahweh to the people. Alternate translation: “Tell them to hurry and sing a song to mourn for you, so your eyes may run with tears and your eyelids flow with water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: Let them hurry and sing a mournful song & and our eyelids flow with water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “each man” refer to both men and women. Alternate translation: “Then I will cause the people to fight with each other, even parents and children will fight one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
contextId.quoteString: smash each man against the other, fathers and children together

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to Jehoiachin as if it were possible for him to be the ring on Yahweh’s hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: even if you & were the signet on my right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh states what would have happened if the priests and false prophets had participated in Yahweh’s council meeting in heaven. This hypothetical situation is impossible. Alternate translation: “if they had truly listened to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: if they had stood in my council meeting

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh knows is not true. Alternate translation: “If they were prophets, and if the word of Yahweh had truly come to them, they would beg” or “Because they are not prophets and the word of Yahweh has not truly come to them, they will not beg” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If they are prophets, and if the word of Yahweh has truly come to them, let them beg

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh never expects to truly happen. Alternate translation: “These permanent things will never vanish … and Israel’s descendants will never stop from forever being a nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Only if these permanent things vanish & will Israel’s descendants ever stop from forever being a nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh never expects to truly happen. Alternate translation: “The highest heavens can never be measured, and the earth’s foundation below can never be discovered, and I will never reject all of Israel’s descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Only if the highest heavens can be measured, and only if the earth’s foundation below can be discovered, will I reject all of Israel’s descendants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words begin a hypothetical statement that describe a situation that will never occur. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If you can break & proper times

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hypothetical statement that begins with the words “If you can break my covenant … times,” in verse 20 ends here. No one can change day and night, and no one can change God’s covenant with David. Alternate translation: “You know that you cannot break my covenant … times, so you know that you will never be able to break my covenant with David my servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: then you will be able to break my covenant with David my servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the beginning of a hypothetical statement that describes a situation that Yahweh never expects to be true.(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If I have not established & and if I have not fixed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hypothetical statement that begins with the words “If I have not established the covenant” in verse 25 ends here. This is a situation that Yahweh never expects to be true. Alternate translation: “I have established the covenant … so I will never reject … and I will bring” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: then I will reject & and not bring

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh does not expect to happen. Alternate translation: “Babylon will not go up … or fortify … destroyers will surely come from me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: if Babylon went up & or fortified & destroyers would come from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the least powerful and least important people. Alternate translation: “the least powerful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the least

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the most powerful and most important people. Alternate translation: “the greatest people” or “the most powerful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the greatest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the least powerful and least important people. Alternate translation: “the least powerful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the least

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the most powerful and most important people. Alternate translation: “the greatest people” or “the most powerful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the greatest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to wicked people. Alternate translation: “wicked people” or “those who are wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to wicked people. Alternate translation: “wicked people” or “those who are wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “the good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the good

contextId.occurrenceNote: This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “with those who were dead” or “with those they had killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: with the dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the nations, so these verbs are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Hear & Report

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were someone else, and he speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a helpless woman. Alternate translation: “I caused my people Israel to be scattered among the nations, but now I am bringing them home and keeping them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The one who scattered Israel is gathering her up and keeping her

contextId.occurrenceNote: These commands and instances of “yourself” and “your” and “you” are addressed to “virgin Israel” and so are singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Place road signs for yourself & Set up guideposts for yourself & Set your mind & you should take & Come back

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each instance of “You” or “you” is plural and refers to the people of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You rejoice & you jump & you neigh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” is plural and refers to the people of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: bore you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reflexive pronoun “yourself” emphasizes the personal risk to the Israelites. Alternate translation: “Do not trust in deceitful words to protect you, saying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not entrust yourself to deceitful words and say

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pronoun, “yourself”, is used here to emphasis the command was specifically for Jeremiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: you yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is emphatic and stresses that Yahweh is the one who will do this. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Then I myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “yourselves” is used for emphasis to specify the people of Judea who live in the land of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You yourselves have seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “themselves” is used for emphasis to specify the people of Jerusalem and the other cities of Judah. Alternate translation: “the people from the ruined cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: they themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “myself” is used to emphasize that Yahweh was the one who knew about Moab’s defiant speech. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself know his defiant speech

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “your” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. The idiom means that Yahweh will do this where they can see. Alternate translation: “in front of you” or “where you can see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: before your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This “You” is singular and refers to the king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You who live

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two instances of “you” are singular and refer to Jeremiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: asks you & you will say

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two instances of “you” are plural and refer to the false prophets and the priests. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You are the burden & cast you off

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is singular and refers to Jeremiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: This is what you will say

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these instances of “you” are plural and refer to the priests and false prophets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: But if you say & Because you have said & when I sent to you & You will not say

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these instances of “you” are plural and refer to the priests and false prophets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: pick you up & throw you & I gave you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This instance of “you” is plural and refers to the priests and false prophets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: insult on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “your” refers to Zedekiah and the people of Judah and so is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Place your necks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people in Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you fight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural. This could mean: (1) this refers to Jeremiah and those with him, or (2) it refers to all the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: which you are saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you are saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to Baruch and Jeremiah and so is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: where you are

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the two men that king Zedekiah had sent to Jeremiah, Jehukal son of Shelemiah, and Zephaniah son of Maaseiah the priest. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you will say

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The Chaldeans will not give you over to the Judeans.” Here “you” refers to Zedekiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: They will not give you over to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “you” and “yourself” refer to Edom, which represents the people of Edom. The word “yourself” is used to draw attention to the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “you yourselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: you yourself

dublin_core.creator: Door43 World Missions Community
dublin_core.description: Open-licensed exegetical notes that provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information for translators. It provides translators and checkers with pertinent, just-in-time information to help them make the best possible translation decisions.
dublin_core.subject: TSV Translation Notes
dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “70 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: seventy years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Jonathan, who was a scribe.” This is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: Jonathan the scribe

contextId.occurrenceNote: “30 men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: thirty men

contextId.occurrenceNote: “80 men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: eighty men

contextId.occurrenceNote: “three thousand and twenty-three” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
“teight hundred and thirty-two” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
“seven hundred and forty-five … four thousand six hundred” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
The word “thirteenth” is the ordinal form of “13.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the thirteenth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “eleventh” is the ordinal form of “11.”(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the eleventh

contextId.occurrenceNote: (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the fourth & the first

contextId.occurrenceNote: See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]]
contextId.quoteString: ninth & tenth

contextId.occurrenceNote: See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]]
contextId.quoteString: eleventh & fourth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “second” is the ordinal form of the number 2. This could mean: (1) “the day after” or (2) “two days after” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the second day after

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fourth” is the ordinal form of the number four. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: fourth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fourth” is the ordinal form of “four.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the fourth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “after he had been king for three years.” This “fourth” is the ordinal number for four. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fourth year of his reign

contextId.occurrenceNote: after Zedekiah had been king for eight years, in the tenth calendar month, on the tenth day of the month (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ninth year of the reign of King Zedekiah, in the tenth month, and on the tenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in year nine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ninth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: until Zedekiah had been king for more than ten years (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah’s reign

contextId.occurrenceNote: “year eleven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: eleventh year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “during year nineteen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the nineteenth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: seventh

contextId.occurrenceNote: (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: eighteenth

contextId.occurrenceNote: (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty-third

contextId.occurrenceNote: after Jehoiachin had been an exile for more than 36 years (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin
